title: Cranial Nerve Exam
description: Systematic evaluation of all twelve cranial nerves to localize lesions in the brainstem, cranial nerve pathways, or peripheral targets.

steps.title: CN I — Olfactory
steps.instruction: Test each nostril separately with a familiar, non-irritating scent such as coffee or vanilla.
steps.technique: Occlude one nostril and hold the scent container approximately 10 cm from the open nostril. Ask the patient to identify or confirm the smell. Repeat on the opposite side.
steps.normalResult: Patient correctly identifies or detects the scent bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: May indicate olfactory groove meningioma, prior head trauma with cribriform plate fracture, or neurodegenerative disease such as Parkinson disease.

steps.title: CN II — Optic
steps.instruction: Assess visual acuity, visual fields by confrontation, and perform fundoscopic examination.
steps.technique: Test each eye independently using a Snellen chart or near card. For visual fields, stand at arm's length and compare your fields with the patient's by wiggling fingers in each quadrant. Perform fundoscopy to evaluate the optic disc.
steps.normalResult: Visual acuity correctable to 20/20, full visual fields to confrontation, sharp optic disc margins.

abnormalResults.significance: Homonymous hemianopia suggests a retrochiasmal lesion; bitemporal hemianopia suggests chiasmal compression such as pituitary adenoma.
Indicates elevated intracranial pressure; requires urgent neuroimaging.

steps.title: CN III — Oculomotor
steps.instruction: Evaluate pupillary response, eyelid elevation, and extraocular movements in the directions controlled by CN III.
steps.technique: Shine a penlight into each eye and observe the direct and consensual pupillary response. Assess for ptosis. Test adduction, elevation, and depression of each eye by having the patient follow your finger through the cardinal positions of gaze.
steps.normalResult: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. No ptosis. Full adduction, supraduction, and infraduction.

abnormalResults.finding: CN III palsy with pupil involvement
abnormalResults.significance: Fixed dilated pupil with ptosis and a 'down and out' eye suggests compression by aneurysm (especially posterior communicating artery) — a neurosurgical emergency.

abnormalResults.finding: CN III palsy with pupil sparing
abnormalResults.significance: More commonly caused by microvascular ischemia (diabetes, hypertension); pupillary fibers run peripherally and are spared in ischemic lesions.

steps.title: CN IV — Trochlear
steps.instruction: Test the superior oblique muscle by evaluating intorsion and depression of the adducted eye.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to look toward the nose (adduct), then look downward. Observe for difficulty with this movement. Check for a compensatory head tilt away from the affected side.
steps.normalResult: Smooth downward movement of the adducted eye bilaterally. No head tilt.

abnormalResults.significance: Vertical diplopia worse on looking down and toward the opposite side; compensatory head tilt. Most common cause is trauma; may also be congenital.

steps.title: CN V — Trigeminal
steps.instruction: Test facial sensation in all three divisions (V1, V2, V3) and assess motor function of the muscles of mastication.
steps.technique: Use a cotton wisp for light touch and a pin for pinprick over the forehead (V1), cheek (V2), and jaw (V3) bilaterally. Ask the patient to clench the jaw and feel the masseter bulk. Test the jaw jerk reflex by tapping the chin with a reflex hammer while the mouth is slightly open.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric sensation in all three divisions. Strong jaw clench bilaterally. Normal or absent jaw jerk.

abnormalResults.significance: Unilateral loss in one or more divisions suggests trigeminal neuropathy, cerebellopontine angle tumor, or brainstem lesion.
Indicates bilateral upper motor neuron disease above the mid-pons, as seen in pseudobulbar palsy or ALS.

steps.title: CN VI — Abducens
steps.instruction: Test lateral rectus function by evaluating abduction of each eye.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to follow your finger laterally to each side. Observe for failure of the eye to fully abduct and for the presence of horizontal diplopia at lateral gaze.
steps.normalResult: Full abduction bilaterally without diplopia.

abnormalResults.significance: Esotropia and horizontal diplopia worst on looking toward the affected side. CN VI has the longest intracranial course and is a false-localizing sign of elevated intracranial pressure.

steps.title: CN VII — Facial
steps.instruction: Assess facial symmetry at rest and with activation; distinguish upper from lower motor neuron patterns.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to raise eyebrows, squeeze eyes shut tightly, smile widely, and puff out cheeks. Attempt to open the squeezed eyelids and assess resistance. Observe for flattening of the nasolabial fold or forehead asymmetry.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric forehead wrinkling, eye closure, and smile. Equal nasolabial folds.

abnormalResults.significance: Weakness of the lower face only with forehead sparing indicates a contralateral hemispheric lesion such as stroke.
Weakness of the entire hemiface including the forehead suggests Bell palsy, Ramsay Hunt syndrome, or cerebellopontine angle pathology.

steps.title: CN VIII — Vestibulocochlear
steps.instruction: Assess hearing bilaterally and perform Weber and Rinne tuning fork tests.
steps.technique: Rub fingers near each ear to screen hearing. Place a vibrating 512 Hz tuning fork on the vertex (Weber) and then on the mastoid followed by the external auditory canal (Rinne) for each ear.
steps.normalResult: Weber midline. Rinne positive bilaterally (air conduction greater than bone conduction). Symmetric hearing to finger rub.

abnormalResults.significance: Weber lateralizes to the normal ear; Rinne remains positive on the affected side. Consider acoustic neuroma, Meniere disease, or ototoxic medications.
Weber lateralizes to the affected ear; Rinne negative on the affected side. Suggests middle ear pathology such as otitis media or otosclerosis.

steps.title: CN IX — Glossopharyngeal
steps.instruction: Evaluate the gag reflex and sensation of the posterior pharynx.
steps.technique: Touch the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a tongue depressor and observe the gag response. Ask the patient about taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric gag reflex bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: May indicate a lesion of CN IX or CN X. Isolated CN IX palsies are rare; typically occurs with CN X involvement in jugular foramen syndrome.

steps.title: CN X — Vagus
steps.instruction: Assess palatal elevation and voice quality.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to say 'Ah' and observe for symmetric elevation of the soft palate. Listen for hoarseness, nasal quality of speech, or dysphonia.
steps.normalResult: Soft palate elevates symmetrically in the midline. Voice is clear and strong.

abnormalResults.significance: The uvula deviates away from the affected side due to unopposed contraction of the intact side. Consider brainstem lesion, skull base tumor, or post-surgical injury.
Unilateral vocal cord paralysis from recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement, which may occur with aortic arch pathology, mediastinal mass, or post-thyroidectomy.

steps.title: CN XI — Spinal Accessory
steps.instruction: Test strength of the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to shrug shoulders against resistance (trapezius) and turn the head to each side against your hand (sternocleidomastoid). The SCM turns the head to the contralateral side, so a right SCM lesion causes weakness turning the head to the left.
steps.normalResult: Full strength of shoulder shrug and head turning bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Shoulder droop and inability to shrug on the affected side. May result from surgical injury in the posterior cervical triangle or jugular foramen pathology.

steps.title: CN XII — Hypoglossal
steps.instruction: Inspect the tongue at rest and during protrusion; assess for atrophy or fasciculations.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to open the mouth and observe the tongue resting on the floor of the mouth for fasciculations or wasting. Then ask the patient to protrude the tongue and move it side to side rapidly.
steps.normalResult: Tongue protrudes in the midline. No atrophy or fasciculations. Rapid side-to-side movement is smooth.

abnormalResults.significance: The tongue deviates toward the side of a lower motor neuron lesion due to unopposed contralateral genioglossus. Seen in hypoglossal neuropathy or medullary pathology.
Suggests lower motor neuron degeneration as in ALS or progressive bulbar palsy.

clinicalPearls: A complete cranial nerve exam should be performed in any patient with suspected brainstem, skull base, or cranial nerve pathology.
The pupil-sparing versus pupil-involving distinction in CN III palsy is critical: pupil involvement warrants emergent vascular imaging to rule out posterior communicating artery aneurysm.

title: Motor Examination
description: Systematic evaluation of muscle bulk, tone, strength, and involuntary movements to distinguish upper motor neuron from lower motor neuron pathology.

steps.title: Inspection
steps.instruction: Visually inspect all four extremities and the trunk for muscle bulk, asymmetry, atrophy, fasciculations, and involuntary movements.
steps.technique: Expose the limbs adequately. Compare corresponding muscle groups side to side. Look for visible fasciculations at rest, especially in the tongue, deltoids, and first dorsal interosseous. Note any tremor, dystonia, chorea, or myoclonus.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric muscle bulk without atrophy, fasciculations, or involuntary movements.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests chronic lower motor neuron denervation at the level of the anterior horn cell, nerve root, plexus, or peripheral nerve.
Spontaneous firing of motor units visible under the skin. In the setting of weakness and atrophy, strongly suggests anterior horn cell disease such as ALS.

steps.title: Tone
steps.instruction: Assess muscle tone in the upper and lower extremities by passively moving the joints through their range of motion.
steps.technique: With the patient relaxed, passively flex and extend the elbow, wrist, knee, and ankle. Note the resistance encountered. Roll the forearm and pronate/supinate the wrist to detect cogwheel rigidity. Quickly dorsiflex the ankle to test for clonus.
steps.normalResult: Normal tone with smooth, easy passive movement. No clonus.

abnormalResults.significance: Velocity-dependent increase in tone (clasp-knife quality) indicating an upper motor neuron lesion such as stroke, spinal cord injury, or multiple sclerosis.
Velocity-independent resistance throughout range (lead-pipe or cogwheel) seen in Parkinson disease and other extrapyramidal disorders.

steps.title: Upper Extremity Strength
steps.instruction: Test major muscle groups of the upper extremities using the MRC 0-5 grading scale.
steps.technique: Test deltoid (C5, shoulder abduction), biceps (C5-6, elbow flexion), triceps (C7, elbow extension), wrist extensors (C6-7), wrist flexors (C7-T1), finger extensors (C7), grip strength (C8), and finger abduction (T1). Grade each on the MRC scale: 0=no contraction, 1=flicker, 2=movement with gravity eliminated, 3=movement against gravity, 4=movement against resistance, 5=normal strength.
steps.normalResult: 5/5 strength in all tested muscle groups bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Upper extremity extensors weaker than flexors suggests upper motor neuron pathology (corticospinal tract lesion) as seen in stroke or myelopathy.
Weakness confined to a single myotome (e.g., isolated C7 weakness) suggests radiculopathy from disc herniation or foraminal stenosis.

steps.title: Lower Extremity Strength
steps.instruction: Test major muscle groups of the lower extremities using the MRC 0-5 grading scale.
steps.technique: Test hip flexion (L1-2, iliopsoas), hip extension (L5-S1, gluteus maximus), knee extension (L3-4, quadriceps), knee flexion (L5-S1, hamstrings), ankle dorsiflexion (L4-5, tibialis anterior), ankle plantarflexion (S1-2, gastrocnemius), and great toe extension (L5, extensor hallucis longus). Grade each 0-5.
steps.normalResult: 5/5 strength in all tested muscle groups bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Lower extremity flexors weaker than extensors (opposite to upper extremity pattern) suggests upper motor neuron lesion.
Consider spinal cord pathology (myelopathy), cauda equina syndrome, or polyneuropathy such as Guillain-Barre syndrome.

steps.title: Pronator Drift
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to extend both arms forward with palms up and eyes closed for 10 seconds.
steps.technique: Patient stands or sits upright with both arms extended at shoulder height, palms supinated, fingers spread, and eyes closed. Observe for 10 seconds. A positive test is pronation and downward drift of one arm.
steps.normalResult: Both arms remain in position without drift, pronation, or finger flexion.

abnormalResults.significance: Gradual pronation and downward drift indicates a contralateral upper motor neuron (corticospinal tract) lesion, often from stroke. This is one of the most sensitive tests for subtle pyramidal weakness.
Upward drift with finger movements suggests proprioceptive loss (sensory ataxia) rather than pyramidal weakness. Seen in posterior column disorders.

clinicalPearls: Always distinguish upper motor neuron patterns (spasticity, hyperreflexia, pyramidal weakness) from lower motor neuron patterns (flaccidity, hyporeflexia, atrophy, fasciculations).
Pronator drift is more sensitive than formal strength testing for detecting subtle corticospinal tract lesions.

title: Sensory Examination
description: Assessment of primary sensory modalities (spinothalamic and dorsal column pathways) and cortical sensory processing to localize lesions in the peripheral nerve, spinal cord, or brain.

steps.title: Light Touch
steps.instruction: Test light touch perception using a cotton wisp over dermatomes of the upper and lower extremities and trunk.
steps.technique: With the patient's eyes closed, lightly touch the skin with a cotton wisp. Test each dermatome from C4 to T12 on the trunk and C5-T1 and L2-S1 on the extremities. Ask the patient to say 'yes' when they feel the touch. Compare side to side at each level.
steps.normalResult: Light touch perceived symmetrically in all dermatomes.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss in a single dermatome suggests nerve root compression (radiculopathy). A sensory level on the trunk suggests spinal cord pathology.
Length-dependent sensory loss starting distally suggests peripheral polyneuropathy, commonly from diabetes, alcohol, or vitamin B12 deficiency.

steps.title: Pinprick
steps.instruction: Test pain and temperature sensation (spinothalamic tract) using a disposable neurotip or broken wooden applicator stick.
steps.technique: With the patient's eyes closed, alternate between the sharp and dull end of the pin. Test dermatomes on both sides, moving proximal to distal. Ask the patient to report 'sharp' or 'dull.' Compare sides and proximal versus distal.
steps.normalResult: Patient correctly identifies sharp versus dull symmetrically in all tested areas.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss of pinprick and temperature with preserved proprioception and vibration in a cape-like distribution suggests a central cord lesion such as syringomyelia.
Contralateral loss below a spinal level suggests a Brown-Sequard pattern (lateral cord hemisection). Loss of pinprick contralateral to motor weakness localizes to the cord.

steps.title: Vibration
steps.instruction: Test vibration sense (dorsal column pathway) using a 128 Hz tuning fork on bony prominences.
steps.technique: Strike the tuning fork and place its base on the distal interphalangeal joint of the great toe. Ask the patient when vibration stops and compare to your own perception. If absent distally, move proximally to the medial malleolus, then tibial tuberosity, then anterior superior iliac spine. Repeat for the upper extremities starting at the DIP of the index finger.
steps.normalResult: Vibration perceived at distal bony prominences bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss at the toes with preservation at the ankles or knees indicates large fiber peripheral neuropathy (dorsal column fibers). Common in B12 deficiency, diabetes, and tabes dorsalis.

abnormalResults.finding: Vibration loss below a spinal level
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests ipsilateral dorsal column dysfunction in the spinal cord, as in subacute combined degeneration or multiple sclerosis.

steps.title: Proprioception
steps.instruction: Test joint position sense at the distal interphalangeal joints of the toes and fingers.
steps.technique: Grasp the great toe on its lateral aspects (to avoid pressure cues) and demonstrate 'up' and 'down' to the patient. Then with the patient's eyes closed, make small excursions and ask the patient to identify the direction. Errors at the toe should prompt testing at the ankle, then the knee. Repeat for finger DIP joints.
steps.normalResult: Patient correctly identifies direction of small movements at the toes and fingers.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss of joint position sense indicates dorsal column or large sensory fiber dysfunction. Causes sensory ataxia with positive Romberg sign.

steps.title: Cortical Sensory
steps.instruction: Test cortical sensory processing including graphesthesia, stereognosis, and double simultaneous stimulation.
steps.technique: Graphesthesia: Trace a number (e.g., 8, 3) on the patient's palm with a blunt object and ask them to identify it. Stereognosis: Place a common object (coin, key, paperclip) in the patient's hand with eyes closed and ask them to identify it. Extinction: Simultaneously touch both hands or both cheeks and ask how many points were felt.
steps.normalResult: Patient correctly identifies traced numbers, recognizes objects by touch, and perceives bilateral simultaneous stimulation.

abnormalResults.significance: Inability to identify objects or traced numbers with intact primary sensation indicates a contralateral parietal lobe lesion.
Failure to perceive the stimulus on one side during bilateral simultaneous stimulation suggests contralateral parietal cortex dysfunction (hemispatial neglect).

clinicalPearls: Always compare pinprick and vibration to distinguish spinothalamic (anterolateral) from dorsal column pathology, which is critical for spinal cord localization.
A sensory level on the trunk is highly suggestive of myelopathy and should prompt urgent MRI of the spine.

title: Deep Tendon Reflexes
description: Assessment of monosynaptic stretch reflexes at standard sites to evaluate the integrity of the reflex arc and detect upper or lower motor neuron dysfunction.

steps.title: Biceps (C5-C6)
steps.instruction: Elicit the biceps reflex by tapping the biceps tendon at the antecubital fossa.
steps.technique: With the patient's arm relaxed and slightly flexed at the elbow, place your thumb over the biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa. Strike your thumb with the reflex hammer. Observe for flexion at the elbow. Grade 0-4: 0=absent, 1+=hypoactive, 2+=normal, 3+=hyperactive without clonus, 4+=hyperactive with clonus.
steps.normalResult: 2+ brisk contraction with elbow flexion bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests lower motor neuron lesion at C5-C6 level: C5-C6 radiculopathy, musculocutaneous neuropathy, or peripheral neuropathy.
Suggests upper motor neuron lesion above C5 level: cervical myelopathy, stroke, or demyelinating disease.

steps.title: Triceps (C7)
steps.instruction: Elicit the triceps reflex by tapping the triceps tendon just above the olecranon.
steps.technique: Support the patient's arm so the elbow is flexed at 90 degrees. Identify the triceps tendon approximately 2 cm above the olecranon process. Strike the tendon directly with the reflex hammer. Observe for elbow extension.
steps.normalResult: 2+ brisk contraction with elbow extension bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests C7 radiculopathy (most common cervical radiculopathy), radial nerve lesion, or diffuse polyneuropathy.
Tapping the triceps produces finger flexion instead of elbow extension, indicating a C7 level spinal cord lesion with compression at that level.

steps.title: Brachioradialis (C5-C6)
steps.instruction: Elicit the brachioradialis reflex by tapping the distal radius approximately 10 cm above the wrist.
steps.technique: Rest the patient's forearm in a semi-pronated position on their lap or on a support. Strike the styloid process of the radius. Observe for flexion at the elbow and slight forearm pronation.
steps.normalResult: 2+ with elbow flexion and forearm pronation bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Absence of the expected brachioradialis contraction with exaggerated finger flexion indicates a C5-C6 level spinal cord lesion. This is a highly localizing sign of cervical myelopathy at that level.
Suggests C5-C6 radiculopathy or peripheral nerve lesion affecting the reflex arc.

steps.title: Patellar (L3-L4)
steps.instruction: Elicit the knee jerk by tapping the patellar tendon.
steps.technique: With the patient seated and legs dangling, or supine with the knee slightly flexed over your supporting arm, tap the patellar tendon just below the patella. If the reflex is difficult to obtain, use Jendrassik maneuver (have the patient interlock fingers and pull apart while you strike). Observe for quadriceps contraction and knee extension.
steps.normalResult: 2+ brisk knee extension bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests L3-L4 radiculopathy, femoral neuropathy, or peripheral polyneuropathy. Bilateral absence is common in diabetic neuropathy.
Tapping the patellar tendon on one side causes contraction of the contralateral adductors, indicating upper motor neuron dysfunction above the lumbar cord.

steps.title: Achilles (S1)
steps.instruction: Elicit the ankle jerk by tapping the Achilles tendon.
steps.technique: Dorsiflex the ankle slightly to put the tendon on stretch. Tap the Achilles tendon with the reflex hammer. Observe for plantarflexion at the ankle. If absent, try the Jendrassik maneuver or have the patient kneel on a chair with feet hanging off the edge. Test for sustained clonus by briskly dorsiflexing the ankle and holding pressure.
steps.normalResult: 2+ brisk plantarflexion bilaterally. No sustained clonus.

abnormalResults.significance: The earliest reflex to be lost in peripheral polyneuropathy. Also seen in S1 radiculopathy (L5-S1 disc herniation) and sciatic neuropathy.
Rhythmic involuntary oscillation at the ankle indicates marked upper motor neuron dysfunction. Seen in myelopathy, stroke, or other corticospinal tract lesions.

clinicalPearls: Always use the Jendrassik maneuver (patient clenches hands while you test lower extremity reflexes) before calling a reflex truly absent.
The combination of hyperreflexia in the legs with hyporeflexia in the arms at a specific level is the hallmark of cervical myelopathy and pinpoints the level of cord compression.

title: Cerebellar Exam
description: Evaluation of cerebellar function including coordination, balance, and gait to identify cerebellar hemispheric or midline (vermis) pathology.

steps.title: Finger-Nose-Finger
steps.instruction: Test upper extremity coordination by having the patient alternate between touching their nose and your finger.
steps.technique: Hold your index finger at arm's length from the patient. Ask the patient to touch their nose, then your finger, then their nose, repeatedly. Move your finger to different positions. Observe for intention tremor (worsening as the finger approaches the target), dysmetria (overshooting or undershooting), and decomposition of movement.
steps.normalResult: Smooth, accurate movements from nose to target without tremor or dysmetria.

abnormalResults.significance: Oscillation that worsens as the finger approaches the target indicates ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere dysfunction. Causes include stroke, multiple sclerosis, or cerebellar mass.
Consistently overshooting the target suggests ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere or cerebellar outflow tract pathology.

steps.title: Heel-Knee-Shin
steps.instruction: Test lower extremity coordination by having the patient run one heel down the opposite shin.
steps.technique: With the patient supine, ask them to place one heel on the opposite knee and slide it smoothly down the shin to the ankle, then lift it back to the knee and repeat. Observe for irregular trajectory, side-to-side oscillation, and difficulty maintaining contact with the shin.
steps.normalResult: Smooth, straight movement of heel along the shin without lateral deviation.

abnormalResults.significance: Side-to-side wavering of the heel as it descends the shin indicates ipsilateral cerebellar dysfunction. Helps lateralize cerebellar lesions.

steps.title: Rapid Alternating Movements
steps.instruction: Test rapid alternating movements (dysdiadochokinesia) in the upper extremities.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to rapidly alternate between pronating and supinating one hand on the opposite palm, or to rapidly tap the thumb to each finger sequentially. Observe for speed, rhythm, and accuracy. Test each hand separately.
steps.normalResult: Rapid, smooth, rhythmic alternating movements bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Irregular, slow, and clumsy alternating movements indicate ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere dysfunction. One of the most sensitive tests for cerebellar pathology.

steps.title: Romberg Test
steps.instruction: Assess the contribution of proprioception to standing balance.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to stand with feet together and arms at the sides. Observe for 30 seconds with eyes open, then ask them to close their eyes. Stand close enough to catch the patient if they fall. A positive Romberg is significant sway or falling only when the eyes are closed.
steps.normalResult: Patient maintains balance with eyes open and closed without significant sway.

abnormalResults.significance: Falling only with eyes closed indicates a sensory ataxia (dorsal column or peripheral proprioceptive dysfunction), not a cerebellar lesion. Cerebellar ataxia causes imbalance with eyes both open and closed.

abnormalResults.finding: Instability with eyes open and closed
abnormalResults.significance: Inability to maintain balance even with eyes open suggests cerebellar vermis pathology or severe vestibular dysfunction.

steps.title: Tandem Gait
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to walk heel-to-toe in a straight line.
steps.technique: Demonstrate heel-to-toe walking and ask the patient to walk at least 10 steps in a straight line. Observe for difficulty placing one foot directly in front of the other, lateral veering, or need to widen the base. Stand alongside the patient for safety.
steps.normalResult: Patient walks heel-to-toe in a straight line without sway or missteps.

abnormalResults.finding: Truncal ataxia with inability to tandem walk
abnormalResults.significance: Difficulty with tandem gait is the most sensitive test for midline cerebellar (vermis) dysfunction. Causes include alcohol-related cerebellar degeneration and posterior fossa tumors.

clinicalPearls: Cerebellar hemisphere lesions cause ipsilateral limb ataxia (dysmetria, dysdiadochokinesia), while vermis lesions cause primarily truncal ataxia and gait instability.
A positive Romberg sign is not a cerebellar finding; it indicates proprioceptive or vestibular sensory loss. True cerebellar ataxia is present with eyes both open and closed.

title: Gait Examination
description: Systematic assessment of gait patterns to localize neurological pathology including upper motor neuron, lower motor neuron, cerebellar, extrapyramidal, and sensory disorders.

steps.title: Casual Gait
steps.instruction: Observe the patient walking at their natural pace across the room and back.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to walk at their normal speed across a well-lit room for at least 20 feet, turn around, and walk back. Observe stride length, step height, base width, arm swing, posture, and turning stability. Note any asymmetry or compensatory movements.
steps.normalResult: Smooth, symmetric gait with normal stride length, arm swing, upright posture, and easy turning.

abnormalResults.significance: Stiff, circumducting leg with reduced flexion indicates upper motor neuron lesion. Unilateral suggests stroke; bilateral (scissoring) suggests myelopathy or bilateral hemispheric disease.
Short shuffling steps, reduced arm swing, flexed posture, festination, and en-bloc turning suggest Parkinson disease or other parkinsonian disorder.

steps.title: Tandem Walk
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to walk heel-to-toe in a straight line.
steps.technique: Demonstrate the technique and have the patient walk at least 10 steps heel-to-toe. Observe for lateral swaying, stepping off the line, or widening of the base. Stand alongside for safety.
steps.normalResult: Patient walks heel-to-toe smoothly without sway or difficulty.

abnormalResults.significance: Inability to maintain tandem gait with lateral swaying is the most sensitive test for midline cerebellar dysfunction, vestibular pathology, or posterior fossa lesions.

steps.title: Heel Walk
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to walk on their heels for at least 10 steps.
steps.technique: Demonstrate walking on the heels with toes elevated off the ground. Ask the patient to walk 10 steps. This primarily tests ankle dorsiflexion (L4-L5, deep peroneal nerve, tibialis anterior). Observe for foot drop or difficulty maintaining the position.
steps.normalResult: Patient walks on heels with toes fully elevated and without difficulty.

abnormalResults.significance: Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion suggests L4-L5 radiculopathy, peroneal (fibular) neuropathy, or sciatic neuropathy. Also weak in distal motor neuropathies.

steps.title: Toe Walk
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to walk on their toes for at least 10 steps.
steps.technique: Demonstrate walking on the balls of the feet with heels elevated. Ask the patient to walk 10 steps. This primarily tests ankle plantarflexion (S1-S2, tibial nerve, gastrocnemius-soleus). Observe for difficulty rising on the toes or asymmetry.
steps.normalResult: Patient walks on toes with heels fully elevated and without difficulty.

abnormalResults.significance: Weakness of plantarflexion suggests S1 radiculopathy, tibial neuropathy, or peripheral polyneuropathy. Since plantarflexion is a strong muscle group, mild weakness may be masked.

steps.title: Romberg
steps.instruction: Assess balance with feet together and eyes closed to test proprioceptive input.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to stand with feet together and arms at sides. Observe for 30 seconds with eyes open, then with eyes closed. A positive Romberg is marked sway or loss of balance only when eyes are closed. Stand close to prevent falling.
steps.normalResult: Patient maintains balance with feet together and eyes closed without significant sway.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss of balance with eyes closed but not eyes open indicates proprioceptive (dorsal column) or vestibular dysfunction. The visual system was compensating for impaired proprioception.

abnormalResults.finding: Unable to stand with feet together even with eyes open
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests cerebellar pathology, severe vestibular dysfunction, or severe motor weakness. This is not a true positive Romberg but indicates a broader balance disorder.

clinicalPearls: Gait is the single most integrative neurological function, requiring intact motor, sensory, cerebellar, vestibular, and cognitive systems. It often reveals pathology missed by bedside testing.
A steppage gait (high-stepping to clear a dropped foot) suggests peroneal neuropathy or L5 radiculopathy, and can be confirmed by inability to heel walk.

title: Meningeal Signs
description: Assessment for meningeal irritation caused by infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or carcinomatous meningitis.

steps.title: Nuchal Rigidity
steps.instruction: Passively flex the patient's neck to assess for resistance to flexion.
steps.technique: With the patient supine and relaxed, place one hand behind the head and gently flex the neck, bringing the chin toward the chest. True nuchal rigidity is resistance to flexion (not extension or rotation). The resistance should feel involuntary and is often accompanied by pain. Distinguish from cervical spondylosis (resistance in all directions) or paratonia (generalized increased tone in dementia).
steps.normalResult: Full, painless passive neck flexion with chin easily reaching the chest.

abnormalResults.significance: Resistance to passive neck flexion suggests meningeal irritation from bacterial meningitis, viral meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or carcinomatous meningitis. Sensitivity is approximately 30% for bacterial meningitis, so absence does not rule it out.

steps.title: Kernig Sign
steps.instruction: With the hip flexed to 90 degrees, attempt to extend the knee and observe for pain or resistance.
steps.technique: With the patient supine, flex one hip and knee to 90 degrees each. Then slowly extend the knee while maintaining hip flexion. A positive Kernig sign is pain or resistance to knee extension beyond 135 degrees, often accompanied by involuntary flexion of the opposite hip.
steps.normalResult: Full knee extension achieved without pain or resistance while hip is flexed.

abnormalResults.significance: Pain or involuntary resistance to knee extension with hip flexion indicates meningeal irritation. Sensitivity is only 5-10% for bacterial meningitis, but specificity is high when present.

steps.title: Brudzinski Sign
steps.instruction: Observe for involuntary hip and knee flexion during passive neck flexion.
steps.technique: With the patient supine and legs extended, passively flex the neck by lifting the head toward the chest. Observe the lower extremities. A positive Brudzinski sign is involuntary flexion of the hips and knees in response to neck flexion.
steps.normalResult: No hip or knee flexion occurs during passive neck flexion.

abnormalResults.significance: Involuntary hip and knee flexion during neck flexion indicates meningeal irritation and stretching of inflamed meninges across the lumbosacral nerve roots. Like Kernig, it has low sensitivity but high specificity.

steps.title: Jolt Accentuation
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to rotate the head rapidly side to side at 2-3 rotations per second and report worsening headache.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to turn the head horizontally side to side at about 2-3 rotations per second for several seconds. A positive test is worsening of headache with this maneuver. The test relies on jolt-induced vibration of inflamed meninges. Not reliable in patients with baseline severe headache.
steps.normalResult: No worsening of headache with horizontal head rotation.

abnormalResults.significance: Worsening headache with rapid head rotation has a reported sensitivity of approximately 97% for meningitis in patients with fever and headache. A negative test in a low-risk patient may help reduce the need for lumbar puncture, though this finding remains debated.

clinicalPearls: No single meningeal sign is sensitive enough to rule out meningitis. Nuchal rigidity is the most commonly tested but has sensitivity of only 30%. Clinical suspicion should drive the decision to perform lumbar puncture.
Meningeal signs may be absent early in the course of bacterial meningitis, in immunocompromised patients, and in the elderly. Do not rely on their absence to exclude the diagnosis.

title: Coma Examination
description: Systematic bedside evaluation of the comatose patient to determine the level and cause of impaired consciousness, localize the lesion, and assess brainstem function.

steps.title: Consciousness Level
steps.instruction: Determine the depth of impaired consciousness using the Glasgow Coma Scale and verbal/motor responsiveness.
steps.technique: Assess eye opening: spontaneous (4), to voice (3), to pain (2), none (1). Verbal response: oriented (5), confused (4), inappropriate words (3), incomprehensible sounds (2), none (1). Motor response: obeys commands (6), localizes pain (5), withdrawal (4), abnormal flexion (3), extension (2), none (1). Apply nail bed pressure or sternal rub as the noxious stimulus. Total GCS range is 3-15.
steps.normalResult: GCS 15: eyes open spontaneously, oriented verbal responses, obeys commands.

abnormalResults.significance: Defines coma. Patient does not open eyes, speak intelligibly, or follow commands. Airway protection is compromised and intubation should be considered.
Localizing on one side with withdrawal or flexion on the other suggests a structural hemispheric lesion (stroke, hemorrhage, mass) contralateral to the localizing side.

steps.title: Pupils
steps.instruction: Evaluate pupillary size, symmetry, and reactivity to light.
steps.technique: In a dimly lit room, measure pupil diameter in millimeters. Shine a bright penlight into each eye and observe the direct and consensual responses. Note the speed and completeness of constriction. Pupil reactivity is a brainstem function that is resistant to metabolic suppression.
steps.normalResult: Pupils equal, round, 3-4 mm, briskly reactive to light bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Ipsilateral CN III compression from uncal herniation until proven otherwise. This is a neurosurgical emergency requiring immediate imaging and potential decompression.
Suggests midbrain lesion disrupting both sympathetic and parasympathetic pathways. Seen in central herniation or midbrain infarction.

steps.title: Oculocephalic / Oculovestibular Reflexes
steps.instruction: Test brainstem-mediated eye movements using the doll's eye maneuver or cold water calorics.
steps.technique: Oculocephalic (doll's eyes): Only if cervical spine is cleared. Hold eyelids open and briskly turn the head side to side. Normal response: eyes deviate conjugately opposite to head turning (intact brainstem). Cold caloric: Confirm intact tympanic membrane. Elevate head 30 degrees. Irrigate one ear with 50 mL ice water over 30 seconds. Normal brainstem response in coma: tonic deviation of eyes toward the irrigated ear. Wait 5 minutes between ears.
steps.normalResult: Intact oculocephalic reflex with conjugate eye deviation opposite to head turning. Cold calorics produce tonic deviation toward the irrigated ear.

abnormalResults.significance: Loss of all brainstem-mediated eye movements indicates severe pontine dysfunction. This is one of the prerequisites for brain death determination.
Eyes that do not move together suggest a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (internuclear ophthalmoplegia) or individual cranial nerve nucleus damage in the brainstem.

steps.title: Corneal Reflex
steps.instruction: Test the corneal reflex by touching the cornea and observing for bilateral eye closure.
steps.technique: Gently touch the cornea (not the sclera or conjunctiva) with a sterile cotton wisp or drop of saline. The afferent limb is CN V1 (ophthalmic) and the efferent limb is CN VII (facial) bilaterally. Observe for a blink response in both eyes.
steps.normalResult: Brisk bilateral eye closure (blink) when either cornea is stimulated.

abnormalResults.significance: If afferent (no response when touching the affected side but normal when touching the contralateral cornea), suggests CN V lesion. If efferent (no blink on affected side regardless of which cornea is touched), suggests CN VII lesion.
Indicates severe pontine dysfunction involving both CN V and VII nuclei. Along with absent calorics, suggests extensive brainstem damage.

steps.title: Motor Patterns
steps.instruction: Characterize spontaneous and stimulus-evoked motor patterns in the comatose patient.
steps.technique: Observe for spontaneous movements, posturing, myoclonus, or seizure activity. Apply central pain (sternal rub, trapezius squeeze) and peripheral pain (nail bed pressure). Classify responses as purposeful/localizing, withdrawal, decorticate (abnormal flexion of arms with extension of legs), or decerebrate (extension of all extremities with internal rotation and plantarflexion).
steps.normalResult: Patient localizes to pain bilaterally with purposeful movements.

abnormalResults.significance: Flexion of upper extremities and extension of lower extremities to noxious stimuli suggests a lesion above the red nucleus (hemispheric or internal capsule). The corticospinal tract below the red nucleus is intact.
Extension and internal rotation of all four extremities suggests a lesion at the level of the midbrain or upper pons, below the red nucleus. Carries a worse prognosis than decorticate posturing.

steps.title: Respiratory Pattern
steps.instruction: Observe the patient's respiratory pattern, which can help localize the level of brainstem dysfunction.
steps.technique: Observe the respiratory rate, rhythm, and depth without supplemental oxygen if safe to do so. Note the pattern over at least 2-3 minutes. Cheyne-Stokes = periodic crescendo-decrescendo hyperpnea alternating with apnea. Central neurogenic hyperventilation = sustained rapid deep breathing. Apneustic = prolonged inspiratory pause. Ataxic (Biot) = irregular rate and depth.
steps.normalResult: Regular respiratory rate and rhythm (12-20 breaths per minute).

abnormalResults.significance: Periodic crescendo-decrescendo breathing alternating with apnea indicates bilateral hemispheric or diencephalic dysfunction. May also be seen in congestive heart failure.
Completely irregular respiratory pattern with variable rate and depth indicates medullary dysfunction. This is an ominous sign suggesting impending respiratory arrest and need for intubation.

clinicalPearls: Pupil reactivity is the single most important brainstem sign in the comatose patient. Reactive pupils in an unresponsive patient suggest a metabolic or toxic cause rather than structural damage.
The coma exam must be interpreted cautiously after administration of sedatives, paralytics, or atropine-containing drugs, which can abolish brainstem reflexes and mimic brain death.

title: Vestibular Examination
description: Targeted evaluation of the peripheral and central vestibular systems to distinguish benign peripheral causes of vertigo from dangerous central causes.

steps.title: Dix-Hallpike Maneuver
steps.instruction: Perform the Dix-Hallpike maneuver to test for posterior canal benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
steps.technique: Seat the patient on the exam table positioned so the head will hang over the edge when supine. Turn the head 45 degrees to one side. Rapidly lower the patient to supine with the head hanging 20 degrees below the table edge, maintaining the 45-degree rotation. Observe the eyes for nystagmus for at least 30 seconds. Note the latency (onset delay), direction, duration, and fatigability. Return the patient to sitting, then repeat on the opposite side.
steps.normalResult: No nystagmus or vertigo in either position.

abnormalResults.significance: Nystagmus with 2-10 second latency, upbeat with torsional component toward the lower ear, lasting <60 seconds, and fatiguing on repeat is classic for posterior canal BPPV. Sensitivity ~79% (range 48-88%), specificity ~75% for BPPV. The affected ear is downward when nystagmus occurs.

abnormalResults.finding: Downbeat nystagmus without latency or fatigue
abnormalResults.significance: Immediate onset, purely vertical (downbeat), non-fatiguing nystagmus is a red flag for central pathology such as cerebellar lesion or Chiari malformation. Requires brain MRI.

steps.title: Head Impulse Test (HIT)
steps.instruction: Perform the bedside head impulse test to evaluate the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR).
steps.technique: Ask the patient to fixate on your nose. Hold the patient's head steady, then make small (10-20 degree) rapid, unpredictable head thrusts to each side. Observe whether the eyes maintain fixation on your nose or whether a corrective saccade (catch-up eye movement) is needed. Test both sides.
steps.normalResult: Eyes remain fixed on the target during rapid head thrusts in both directions (intact VOR).

abnormalResults.significance: A catch-up saccade back to the target after head impulse toward one side indicates ipsilateral peripheral vestibular hypofunction (vestibular neuritis, labyrinthitis). In acute vertigo, a positive HIT is actually reassuring as it points to a peripheral rather than central cause.
A negative (normal) HIT in a patient with acute continuous vertigo and nystagmus is concerning for a central cause such as cerebellar or brainstem stroke. This is a key component of the HINTS exam.

steps.title: HINTS Exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew)
steps.instruction: Perform the complete HINTS battery in acute vestibular syndrome to distinguish peripheral from central causes.
steps.technique: HINTS is only valid in patients with acute vestibular syndrome (continuous vertigo, nystagmus, nausea, gait instability). Three components: (1) Head Impulse Test - normal HIT is concerning for central; (2) Nystagmus - direction-changing nystagmus with gaze is central; (3) Test of Skew - cover-uncover test looking for vertical realignment indicates central. A 'dangerous' HINTS has: normal HIT, direction-changing nystagmus, OR skew deviation.
steps.normalResult: Peripheral pattern: abnormal HIT (corrective saccade), unidirectional nystagmus, no skew deviation.

abnormalResults.significance: Landmark study (Kattah 2009): HINTS sensitivity 96-100%, specificity 96% for stroke in acute vestibular syndrome—more sensitive than MRI in first 48 hours. Central signs: normal HIT, direction-changing nystagmus, or skew deviation. Any single central sign warrants stroke workup.
Adding acute unilateral hearing loss to HINTS increases sensitivity for AICA stroke. Labyrinthine artery is an AICA branch; infarction causes combined vestibular and cochlear symptoms.

steps.title: Fukuda Stepping Test
steps.instruction: Assess for unilateral vestibular dysfunction by having the patient march in place with eyes closed.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to extend both arms forward, close their eyes, and march in place for 50 steps. Mark the starting position and observe for rotation. A positive test is rotation of more than 30-45 degrees toward one side. The patient rotates toward the side of the vestibular hypofunction.
steps.normalResult: Patient remains within 30 degrees of starting orientation without significant rotation.

abnormalResults.finding: Rotation greater than 45 degrees to one side
abnormalResults.significance: Consistent rotation toward one side indicates ipsilateral vestibular hypofunction. The patient drifts toward the weaker labyrinth because of asymmetric tonic vestibular input to the vestibulospinal tracts.

steps.title: Dynamic Visual Acuity
steps.instruction: Compare visual acuity with the head still versus during passive head oscillation to detect vestibular hypofunction.
steps.technique: Measure best-corrected visual acuity on a Snellen chart with the head still. Then oscillate the patient's head passively in the horizontal plane at approximately 2 Hz while the patient reads the chart again. A drop of 2 or more lines on the Snellen chart during head oscillation indicates impaired VOR.
steps.normalResult: Visual acuity drops by no more than 1 line during head oscillation.

abnormalResults.finding: Drop of 2 or more Snellen lines with head movement
abnormalResults.significance: Indicates bilateral vestibular hypofunction (bilateral vestibulopathy) with impaired VOR gain. Causes include ototoxic medications (especially gentamicin), bilateral Meniere disease, or idiopathic bilateral vestibulopathy. Patients often report oscillopsia.

clinicalPearls: The HINTS exam (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, Test of Skew) performed by a trained examiner in acute vestibular syndrome is more sensitive than early MRI for detecting posterior circulation stroke.
In the Dix-Hallpike test, always keep the patient in the provocative position for at least 30 seconds; BPPV nystagmus can have a latency of up to 10 seconds before onset.

title: 5-Minute Neuro Screen
description: A focused, time-efficient neurological screening for use in emergency, primary care, or pre-operative settings to rapidly detect major neurological deficits.

steps.title: Orientation
steps.instruction: Assess level of consciousness and orientation to person, place, time, and situation.
steps.technique: Ask the patient their name, current location, today's date (day, month, year), and why they are here. Note whether they are alert, drowsy, or require stimulation to respond. Assess attentiveness during the interview.
steps.normalResult: Alert, attentive, and oriented to person, place, time, and situation.

abnormalResults.finding: Disorientation or decreased level of consciousness
abnormalResults.significance: Altered mental status may indicate acute stroke, metabolic encephalopathy, intracranial hemorrhage, infection, or medication effects. Requires immediate further evaluation.
Inability to maintain attention suggests delirium or diffuse cerebral dysfunction rather than a focal lesion. Use the months-backward or serial-7s test to confirm.

steps.title: Pupils
steps.instruction: Evaluate pupil size, symmetry, and reactivity to light.
steps.technique: In ambient lighting, estimate pupil diameter bilaterally. Shine a penlight into each eye and observe the direct and consensual responses. Note anisocoria (asymmetry greater than 1 mm).
steps.normalResult: Pupils equal, round, and reactive to light bilaterally (PERRL). No anisocoria.

abnormalResults.finding: New-onset anisocoria with unreactive larger pupil
abnormalResults.significance: A fixed dilated pupil is an emergency sign suggesting CN III compression from uncal herniation, posterior communicating artery aneurysm, or traumatic CN III injury.
May indicate severe brainstem dysfunction, drug effect (atropine, opioids), or post-cardiac arrest brain injury. Context is critical for interpretation.

steps.title: Face-Arm-Leg Strength
steps.instruction: Rapidly screen motor function in the face, upper extremities, and lower extremities for asymmetric weakness.
steps.technique: Face: Ask the patient to show their teeth and observe for asymmetry. Arms: Ask the patient to hold both arms outstretched with palms up and eyes closed for 10 seconds (pronator drift test). Legs: Ask the patient to hold each leg off the bed for 5 seconds against gravity. Compare sides.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric face activation, no pronator drift, and equal leg strength bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Unilateral facial weakness with ipsilateral arm drift is the classic presentation of acute stroke in the contralateral hemisphere. Activate stroke protocol immediately.
Acute bilateral leg weakness may indicate spinal cord compression (myelopathy), cauda equina syndrome, or Guillain-Barre syndrome. Requires urgent evaluation.

steps.title: Sensation
steps.instruction: Quickly screen for gross sensory deficits in the face and all four extremities.
steps.technique: Lightly touch the patient's forehead, both hands, and both feet and ask if the sensation feels normal and symmetric. If abnormal, briefly test pinprick in the same areas. Ask 'Does this feel the same on both sides?'
steps.normalResult: Symmetric light touch sensation in the face and all four extremities.

abnormalResults.significance: Unilateral loss of sensation in the face, arm, and leg suggests a contralateral thalamic or hemispheric lesion, most commonly stroke.
Bilateral distal sensory loss in a stocking distribution suggests peripheral polyneuropathy. Common in diabetic patients. Increases fall risk.

steps.title: Coordination
steps.instruction: Perform a rapid screen of cerebellar function using finger-nose testing and rapid alternating movements.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to touch their nose then your finger alternately, several times with each hand. Then ask the patient to rapidly flip their hand back and forth on their thigh. Observe for dysmetria, intention tremor, or dysdiadochokinesia.
steps.normalResult: Smooth, accurate finger-nose-finger testing and rapid alternating movements bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests an ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere lesion. In the acute setting, consider cerebellar stroke or hemorrhage.

steps.title: Gait
steps.instruction: Observe the patient walking a short distance if safe to do so.
steps.technique: Ask the patient to stand from a chair without using their hands (tests proximal strength), walk 10 feet, turn around, and walk back. Observe for unsteadiness, asymmetry, base width, and ability to turn. If the patient appears stable, ask them to attempt tandem (heel-to-toe) walking.
steps.normalResult: Steady, symmetric gait with normal base width and smooth turning. Able to tandem walk.

abnormalResults.finding: Inability to walk or severe unsteadiness
abnormalResults.significance: New gait failure in an acute setting may indicate stroke (particularly posterior circulation), acute vestibular syndrome, or acute cerebellar pathology. Requires urgent neuroimaging.
Broad-based, staggering gait with difficulty turning suggests cerebellar dysfunction, vestibular pathology, or severe proprioceptive loss.

clinicalPearls: This 5-minute screen covers the key elements needed to identify stroke, herniation, spinal cord compression, and acute cerebellar pathology. It is not a substitute for a complete neurological examination when time permits.
In the emergency setting, the face-arm-leg strength assessment combined with speech evaluation forms the basis of the FAST (Face, Arms, Speech, Time) stroke screening protocol.

title: Mental Status Examination
description: Comprehensive bedside assessment of cognitive function including attention, memory, language, executive function, and visuospatial abilities.

steps.title: Level of Consciousness
steps.instruction: Assess the patient's alertness and responsiveness before proceeding with cognitive testing.
steps.technique: Observe spontaneous eye opening and responsiveness. Note if the patient is alert, drowsy, lethargic (arousable with verbal stimuli), stuporous (arousable only with noxious stimuli), or comatose (unarousable).
steps.normalResult: Alert, awake, and responsive to verbal interaction.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests delirium or toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. Look for underlying infection, medication effects, or metabolic derangement.
May indicate increasing intracranial pressure, expanding mass lesion, or worsening metabolic state. Requires urgent evaluation.

steps.title: Orientation
steps.instruction: Test orientation to person, place, time, and situation.
steps.technique: Ask: 'What is your name?', 'Where are we right now?', 'What is today's date (day, month, year)?', 'Why are you here?' Document as oriented x4, x3, etc.
steps.normalResult: Oriented to person, place, time, and situation (oriented x4).

abnormalResults.significance: Often the first sign of cognitive impairment. Temporal orientation is most sensitive to early dementia or delirium.
Indicates more severe encephalopathy or advanced dementia. Person orientation is typically preserved until late stages.

steps.title: Attention and Concentration
steps.instruction: Test the ability to focus and maintain attention using digit span or serial subtraction.
steps.technique: Digit span forward: Read a series of numbers at 1/second and ask the patient to repeat them (normal ≥5). Serial 7s: Ask patient to subtract 7 from 100 repeatedly (stop after 5 subtractions). Alternative: spell WORLD backwards.
steps.normalResult: Digit span forward ≥5 digits. Serial 7s completed with ≤2 errors. WORLD spelled correctly backwards (DLROW).

abnormalResults.significance: Highly suggestive of delirium rather than dementia. Delirium is characterized primarily by inattention.
Indicates severe attentional impairment. Patient may not be able to participate in further cognitive testing reliably.

steps.title: Memory - Registration
steps.instruction: Assess immediate memory by having the patient register three words.
steps.technique: Say: 'I will say three words. Please repeat them after me and try to remember them: APPLE, TABLE, PENNY.' Have patient repeat all three words. If unable, repeat up to 3 times until registered.
steps.normalResult: Patient repeats all three words correctly on first trial.

abnormalResults.finding: Cannot register words after multiple trials
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests severe attentional impairment or aphasia rather than pure memory deficit. Cannot assess recall if registration fails.

steps.title: Memory - Delayed Recall
steps.instruction: After 3-5 minutes of intervening tasks, test recall of the three words.
steps.technique: Ask: 'What were the three words I asked you to remember?' Score 0-3 for spontaneous recall. If impaired, provide category cues ('one was a fruit') then multiple choice if still unable.
steps.normalResult: Recalls all three words spontaneously or with minimal cueing.

abnormalResults.finding: Poor spontaneous recall, improves with cues
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests retrieval deficit rather than encoding problem. More consistent with subcortical dementia, depression, or normal aging.
Indicates true encoding deficit. Characteristic of Alzheimer disease and medial temporal lobe pathology (hippocampal dysfunction).

steps.title: Language - Fluency
steps.instruction: Assess spontaneous speech output during conversation.
steps.technique: Listen to the patient's speech during history-taking. Note phrase length, prosody, effort of production, and presence of paraphasic errors (word substitutions). Ask the patient to describe a picture or their typical day.
steps.normalResult: Fluent speech with normal phrase length (>5 words), appropriate prosody, and no paraphasic errors.

abnormalResults.finding: Non-fluent speech with short phrases and effortful production
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests Broca (expressive) aphasia from left frontal lesion. Often associated with right hemiparesis.

abnormalResults.finding: Fluent speech with paraphasic errors and empty content
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests Wernicke (receptive) aphasia from left temporoparietal lesion. Patient may be unaware of errors.

steps.title: Language - Comprehension
steps.instruction: Test auditory comprehension at multiple levels of complexity.
steps.technique: Single step: 'Close your eyes.' Two-step: 'Point to the ceiling, then point to the floor.' Three-step: 'Take this paper in your right hand, fold it in half, and put it on the floor.' Also test yes/no questions: 'Do you put on your shoes before your socks?'
steps.normalResult: Follows all commands correctly including three-step commands. Answers yes/no questions appropriately.

abnormalResults.significance: Classic pattern of Wernicke aphasia. Patient produces fluent but often nonsensical speech and doesn't understand they have a deficit.

abnormalResults.finding: Follows one-step but not multi-step commands
abnormalResults.significance: May indicate working memory impairment, attention deficit, or mild comprehension deficit. Test each component separately.

steps.title: Language - Naming
steps.instruction: Test confrontation naming of objects at varying levels of difficulty.
steps.technique: Point to common objects (pen, watch, button) and ask 'What is this called?' Include low-frequency words (watch stem = 'crown', pen clip). Note circumlocutory responses ('thing you write with' for pen).
steps.normalResult: Correctly names all common objects and most low-frequency items.

abnormalResults.significance: Word-finding difficulty is common in many aphasias and also in Alzheimer disease. Circumlocution (talking around the word) suggests the concept is intact.
Suggests semantic dementia or left temporal pathology affecting semantic knowledge.

steps.title: Language - Repetition
steps.instruction: Test the ability to repeat words and phrases of increasing complexity.
steps.technique: Single words: 'president', 'catastrophe'. Phrases: 'No ifs, ands, or buts.' Sentences: 'The orchestra played and the audience applauded.'
steps.normalResult: Accurately repeats all words and phrases without errors.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests conduction aphasia from lesion in the arcuate fasciculus connecting Wernicke and Broca areas.
Suggests transcortical aphasia (motor or sensory type). The perisylvian language areas are intact but disconnected from other regions.

steps.title: Executive Function
steps.instruction: Assess planning, abstraction, and cognitive flexibility.
steps.technique: Similarities: 'How are an apple and orange alike?' (both fruit = abstract; both round = concrete). Proverb interpretation: 'What does "don't cry over spilled milk" mean?' Luria hand sequences: Demonstrate fist-edge-palm sequence and have patient imitate.
steps.normalResult: Abstract similarities (category responses), appropriate proverb interpretation, and smooth performance of motor sequences.

abnormalResults.finding: Concrete interpretation of proverbs and similarities
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests frontal lobe dysfunction. Also seen in lower educational attainment or intellectual disability.
Inability to switch between movements suggests frontal lobe pathology, particularly supplementary motor area or prefrontal dysfunction.

steps.title: Visuospatial Function
steps.instruction: Test visuospatial abilities and constructional praxis.
steps.technique: Clock drawing: Ask patient to draw a clock face with all numbers and set hands to '10 after 11' (11:10). Intersecting pentagons: Have patient copy two overlapping five-sided figures. Observe for neglect by noting if one side of drawings is incomplete.
steps.normalResult: Clock is circular with all 12 numbers correctly placed and hands pointing to 11 and 2. Pentagons are five-sided with clear intersection.

abnormalResults.finding: Numbers clustered on one side of clock
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests hemispatial neglect, typically from right parietal lesion. Patient may also neglect the left side of drawings.
Suggests executive dysfunction (frontal) rather than pure visuospatial deficit. Numbers may be present but poorly organized.

abnormalResults.finding: Unable to copy pentagons despite understanding task
abnormalResults.significance: Constructional apraxia suggests parietal lobe dysfunction. Right parietal lesions cause more severe constructional deficits.

clinicalPearls: Always assess attention first. If attention is severely impaired (as in delirium), other cognitive domains cannot be reliably tested.
The pattern of deficits helps localize: Memory encoding = medial temporal; Executive = frontal; Visuospatial = parietal; Language = dominant (usually left) hemisphere.
Depression can cause 'pseudodementia' with poor effort and 'I don't know' responses. True dementia patients typically attempt answers even if wrong.
For bedside screening, the MoCA (Montreal Cognitive Assessment) is more sensitive than the MMSE for detecting mild cognitive impairment.

title: Fundoscopic Examination
description: Direct visualization of the optic disc and retinal vessels to assess for papilledema, optic neuropathy, and vascular pathology.

steps.title: Preparation and Approach
steps.instruction: Dim the room lights and explain the procedure to the patient.
steps.technique: Set the ophthalmoscope to 0 diopters for an emmetropic examiner. Use your right eye to examine the patient's right eye, left eye for left eye. Ask the patient to fixate on a distant target. Approach at about 15 degrees temporal to the patient's line of sight.
steps.normalResult: Red reflex visible from approximately 30 cm away.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests media opacity (cataract, vitreous hemorrhage) or retinal detachment. Requires ophthalmology referral.

steps.title: Optic Disc Evaluation
steps.instruction: Identify and carefully examine the optic disc margins, color, and cup-to-disc ratio.
steps.technique: Follow a retinal vessel centrally until you reach the disc. Note the disc margins (sharp vs blurred), color (pink/orange normally), cup size relative to disc diameter (normal C:D ratio <0.5), and presence of spontaneous venous pulsations.
steps.normalResult: Sharp disc margins, pink-orange disc with small central cup (C:D <0.5). Spontaneous venous pulsations may be visible (indicates ICP <180 mmH2O).

abnormalResults.significance: Papilledema indicates elevated intracranial pressure. True papilledema is bilateral. Urgent neuroimaging required; do NOT perform lumbar puncture until mass lesion is excluded.
Optic atrophy from prior optic nerve damage. Causes include prior optic neuritis, ischemic optic neuropathy, compressive lesion, or end-stage papilledema.
Suggests anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) if acute vision loss. In patients >50, check ESR/CRP urgently to rule out giant cell arteritis.
Suggests glaucomatous optic neuropathy. Refer to ophthalmology for intraocular pressure measurement and visual field testing.

steps.title: Retinal Vessels
steps.instruction: Examine the retinal arteries and veins for abnormalities.
steps.technique: Follow vessels from the disc outward in all four quadrants. Compare artery-to-vein diameter ratio (normally 2:3). Look for arteriovenous nicking, copper/silver wiring, hemorrhages, and exudates.
steps.normalResult: Normal artery:vein ratio (2:3), smooth vessel walls, no hemorrhages or exudates.

abnormalResults.significance: Signs of chronic hypertensive retinopathy. Indicates need for blood pressure optimization.

abnormalResults.finding: Flame hemorrhages and cotton wool spots
abnormalResults.significance: Acute hypertensive retinopathy or diabetic retinopathy. In the setting of severe hypertension, indicates end-organ damage.
Classic but not specific for infective endocarditis. Also seen in leukemia, severe anemia, and other conditions.
Sign of central retinal artery occlusion. Ophthalmologic emergency with very limited treatment window.

steps.title: Macula Examination
steps.instruction: Ask the patient to look directly at the light to visualize the macula.
steps.technique: The macula is located 2 disc diameters temporal to the optic disc. It appears darker than surrounding retina with a central light reflex (fovea). Warn the patient this will be bright and brief.
steps.normalResult: Macula appears darker than surrounding retina with visible foveal light reflex. No drusen, hemorrhage, or edema.

abnormalResults.significance: Classic sign of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Also seen in storage diseases (Tay-Sachs, Niemann-Pick). CRAO is an emergency.
Sign of age-related macular degeneration. Soft drusen carry higher risk of progression to wet AMD.
May indicate wet AMD, diabetic macular edema, or vascular occlusion. Requires urgent ophthalmology referral.

clinicalPearls: Absence of spontaneous venous pulsations (SVP) does not necessarily indicate elevated ICP—20% of normal individuals lack visible SVP. However, presence of SVP reliably indicates ICP <180 mmH2O.
Papilledema takes hours to days to develop after ICP elevation. Acute ICP elevation (e.g., acute hemorrhage) may not show papilledema initially.
In suspected giant cell arteritis with acute vision loss, do not wait for biopsy results—start high-dose steroids immediately to prevent fellow eye involvement.

Dilating drops (tropicamide) greatly improve fundoscopic visualization but should be avoided in patients with narrow angles or when pupillary exam is being monitored (e.g., head trauma, ICU patients).

title: Speech and Language Assessment
description: Systematic bedside evaluation of language function to classify aphasia type and localize lesions in the dominant hemisphere language network.

steps.title: Spontaneous Speech Assessment
steps.instruction: Listen to the patient's conversational speech during history-taking.
steps.technique: Note: (1) Fluency - phrase length, prosody, effort; (2) Content - meaningful vs empty words; (3) Paraphasias - phonemic (sound errors: 'spork' for 'fork') or semantic (word errors: 'knife' for 'fork'). Ask open-ended questions like 'Tell me about why you came to the hospital today.'
steps.normalResult: Fluent speech with phrase length >5-6 words, normal prosody, meaningful content, no paraphasic errors.

abnormalResults.finding: Non-fluent, effortful speech with short phrases
abnormalResults.significance: Indicates anterior (Broca's) aphasia from left inferior frontal lesion. Patient often has right hemiparesis and is frustrated by their deficit.

abnormalResults.finding: Fluent speech with frequent paraphasias and poor content
abnormalResults.significance: Indicates posterior (Wernicke's) aphasia from left superior temporal lesion. Patient may be unaware of errors (anosognosia for deficit).

abnormalResults.finding: Halting speech searching for words but grammatically correct
abnormalResults.significance: Anomic aphasia - the mildest and most common aphasia type. Can be seen with many lesion locations or as recovery phase from other aphasias.

steps.title: Auditory Comprehension
steps.instruction: Test understanding of spoken language at progressively complex levels.
steps.technique: Yes/No questions: 'Are you in a hospital?' 'Do you put your shoes on before your socks?' Single commands: 'Close your eyes.' Multi-step: 'Point to the ceiling, then to the door.' Token test (if available): 'Touch the small blue circle after touching the large red square.'
steps.normalResult: Correctly follows complex multi-step commands and answers all yes/no questions appropriately.

abnormalResults.significance: Wernicke's aphasia - the most functionally impairing aphasia because patients cannot understand speech and don't recognize their own errors.

abnormalResults.finding: Comprehension intact for single commands, fails multi-step
abnormalResults.significance: May reflect working memory deficit rather than true comprehension impairment. Also seen in transcortical sensory aphasia.

steps.title: Repetition
steps.instruction: Test the ability to repeat spoken phrases exactly.
steps.technique: Start simple: 'cat', 'president'. Progress to: 'No ifs, ands, or buts' (tests function words). Then: 'The spy fled to Greece' (tests content). Note phonemic errors, omissions, or substitutions.
steps.normalResult: Accurately repeats all words and phrases including 'No ifs, ands, or buts.'

abnormalResults.finding: Cannot repeat despite relatively preserved comprehension and fluency
abnormalResults.significance: Conduction aphasia from lesion in arcuate fasciculus (white matter tract connecting Wernicke's and Broca's areas). Phonemic paraphasias are common.

abnormalResults.finding: Preserved repetition with impaired other language functions
abnormalResults.significance: Transcortical aphasia (motor or sensory depending on fluency). Perisylvian language core is intact but disconnected from other regions.

steps.title: Confrontation Naming
steps.instruction: Test word retrieval by asking the patient to name objects.
steps.technique: Point to objects: watch, pen, button, watch band, pen clip (tests high and low frequency words). Body parts: thumb, knuckle, palm. Note if patient can describe function but not name ('thing you write with').
steps.normalResult: Names common and less common objects correctly without delay or circumlocution.

abnormalResults.significance: Semantic errors (calling a 'pen' a 'pencil') suggest breakdown in semantic knowledge, seen in semantic dementia and Alzheimer disease.
Sound-based errors ('pem' for 'pen') suggest phonological retrieval deficit, common in Broca's and conduction aphasia.

steps.title: Reading
steps.instruction: Test oral reading and reading comprehension.
steps.technique: Oral reading: Have patient read aloud a sentence or paragraph. Include irregular words ('colonel', 'yacht') to test lexical reading. Reading comprehension: Have patient read a command and follow it ('Close your eyes') or match written words to pictures.
steps.normalResult: Reads aloud fluently including irregular words. Demonstrates comprehension of written material.

abnormalResults.finding: Cannot read aloud but comprehends written text
abnormalResults.significance: Pure alexia (alexia without agraphia) - a disconnection syndrome from left occipital lesion with splenium involvement.
Surface dyslexia - impaired lexical route with preserved phonological reading. Seen in semantic dementia.

steps.title: Writing
steps.instruction: Test spontaneous writing and writing to dictation.
steps.technique: Spontaneous: 'Write a sentence about the weather.' Dictation: Dictate words including irregularly spelled words ('yacht', 'choir'). Note spelling errors, letter formation, and content.
steps.normalResult: Writes grammatically correct sentences with proper spelling.

abnormalResults.significance: Pure agraphia is rare and localizes to the dominant superior parietal lobule or second frontal gyrus.
Surface dysgraphia ('yot' for 'yacht') indicates impaired lexical spelling route, often accompanying semantic deficits.

clinicalPearls: The three key parameters for aphasia classification are: Fluency, Comprehension, and Repetition. These determine the eight classic aphasia syndromes.
Fluent + Poor comprehension + Poor repetition = Wernicke's. Non-fluent + Good comprehension + Poor repetition = Broca's. Poor repetition localizes to the perisylvian region.
Crossed aphasia (aphasia from right hemisphere lesion in a right-handed person) occurs in <1% of cases and suggests atypical language dominance.
Global aphasia (non-fluent, poor comprehension, poor repetition) results from large left MCA territory infarction and carries poor prognosis for language recovery.
In acute stroke, aphasia severity can guide treatment decisions—patients with severe aphasia often have large vessel occlusions amenable to thrombectomy.

title: Peripheral Neuropathy Examination
description: Focused examination to characterize the pattern, modalities affected, and severity of peripheral nerve dysfunction.

steps.title: Inspection for Trophic Changes
steps.instruction: Examine the feet and hands for signs of chronic denervation and autonomic dysfunction.
steps.technique: Look for muscle wasting (especially foot intrinsics, thenar/hypothenar eminences), skin changes (shiny, hairless, thin skin), nail dystrophy, and foot deformities (pes cavus, hammer toes). Note any ulcers, calluses, or signs of Charcot arthropathy.
steps.normalResult: No muscle atrophy, normal skin texture, hair distribution, and nail appearance. No foot deformities or ulcers.

abnormalResults.significance: Neuropathic ulcers occur due to sensory loss and repeated trauma. High risk for infection and amputation. Indicates severe sensory neuropathy.
Classic foot deformity of hereditary sensorimotor neuropathies (CMT). Results from imbalance between intrinsic and extrinsic foot muscles.
Neuropathic arthropathy from loss of protective sensation. Most common in diabetes. Requires immobilization to prevent progressive destruction.

steps.title: Light Touch Sensation
steps.instruction: Map the distribution of light touch sensory loss.
steps.technique: Using a cotton wisp or 10g monofilament, test sensation starting distally at the toes and moving proximally. Ask 'Can you feel this?' with eyes closed. Map the upper border of sensory loss on the legs. Test hands if leg involvement is significant.
steps.normalResult: Intact light touch sensation to toes bilaterally. 10g monofilament detected at all plantar sites.

abnormalResults.significance: Classic pattern of distal symmetric polyneuropathy. Most commonly diabetic, also seen with alcohol, B12 deficiency, and many other causes.
Suggests mononeuropathy multiplex (vasculitis, diabetes, sarcoid) or sensory neuronopathy (ganglionopathy). Different workup than length-dependent neuropathy.

abnormalResults.finding: Monofilament detected at ankle but not toes
abnormalResults.significance: Mild-moderate neuropathy. The level of sensory loss correlates with fall risk and ulcer risk.

steps.title: Pinprick and Temperature
steps.instruction: Test small fiber (Aδ and C fiber) function with pinprick.
steps.technique: Using a disposable pin or broken wooden applicator, test pinprick distally to proximally. Ask 'Is this sharp or dull?' Compare right to left. Map the upper border of loss. Temperature testing with a cold tuning fork can substitute.
steps.normalResult: Pinprick perceived as sharp bilaterally and symmetrically to toes.

abnormalResults.finding: Loss of pinprick with preserved vibration
abnormalResults.significance: Small fiber neuropathy. Common causes include diabetes (even prediabetes), amyloidosis, Fabry disease, and idiopathic. Standard EMG/NCS will be normal.
If pinprick/temperature affected more than proprioception, suggests small fiber predominant process. Reverse pattern suggests large fiber disease.

steps.title: Vibration Sense
steps.instruction: Test large fiber function using a 128 Hz tuning fork.
steps.technique: Strike the tuning fork and place firmly on the bony prominence of the great toe IP joint. Ask 'Can you feel buzzing?' and 'Tell me when it stops.' Compare the duration you feel it to when patient reports cessation. Progress proximally (medial malleolus, tibial tuberosity) if impaired distally.
steps.normalResult: Vibration sensed at the great toe for ≥10 seconds or similar duration to the examiner.

abnormalResults.finding: Absent vibration at toes, present at ankle
abnormalResults.significance: Mild-moderate large fiber neuropathy. Common in diabetic polyneuropathy, B12 deficiency, and alcohol-related neuropathy.

abnormalResults.finding: Absent vibration to knees or beyond
abnormalResults.significance: Severe large fiber neuropathy. Also consider dorsal column/posterior column myelopathy if proprioception equally affected without distal weakness.

steps.title: Proprioception (Joint Position Sense)
steps.instruction: Test ability to detect joint movement.
steps.technique: Hold the great toe by its sides (not top and bottom) and move it up or down through a small arc. Ask 'Is your toe moving up or down?' with eyes closed. Normal subjects detect 2-3mm movements. Test more proximal joints if impaired distally.
steps.normalResult: Correctly identifies direction of small toe movements bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Large fiber sensory neuropathy or ganglionopathy. Also consider B12 deficiency, which preferentially affects posterior columns.
Severe proprioceptive loss causing balance impairment that worsens with eyes closed. Falls risk is very high.

steps.title: Distal Motor Examination
steps.instruction: Test strength in muscles innervated by the longest axons.
steps.technique: Toe extension (EHL - L5), toe flexion (FDL/FHL - S1), ankle dorsiflexion (TA - L4/5), ankle plantarflexion (gastrocnemius - S1). For hands: finger abduction (ulnar), thumb abduction (median). Grade using MRC scale (0-5).
steps.normalResult: Full strength (MRC 5/5) in all tested muscle groups bilaterally.

abnormalResults.finding: Weakness of toe extensors > ankle dorsiflexors
abnormalResults.significance: Distal > proximal weakness pattern typical of length-dependent polyneuropathy. EHL weakness may precede ankle weakness.
