Can be due to polyneuropathy, peroneal neuropathy, or L5 radiculopathy. Examine peroneal nerve at fibular head; check for low back symptoms.
Indicates more severe or upper limb predominant neuropathy. Rule out compressive neuropathies (ulnar at elbow, median at wrist).

steps.title: Deep Tendon Reflexes
steps.instruction: Test ankle reflexes which are most sensitive for neuropathy.
steps.technique: With patient seated, dorsiflex the foot slightly and tap the Achilles tendon. If absent, try reinforcement (Jendrassik maneuver - have patient hook fingers and pull while you tap). Also test knee jerks for comparison.
steps.normalResult: Ankle jerks 1-2+ bilaterally, equal and symmetric.

abnormalResults.finding: Absent ankle jerks with normal knee jerks
abnormalResults.significance: Classic pattern in polyneuropathy—reflexes are lost distally first. Also lost early in S1 radiculopathy.
Consider severe polyneuropathy, Guillain-Barré syndrome (if acute), or CIDP. Also seen in diabetes and alcoholic neuropathy.
Mixed picture suggests concurrent myelopathy (B12 deficiency causes both subacute combined degeneration and neuropathy).

steps.title: Gait and Romberg Test
steps.instruction: Assess functional impact of neuropathy on ambulation.
steps.technique: Observe gait for foot slapping (indicates foot drop), wide base (sensory ataxia), or steppage gait. Perform Romberg test: patient stands with feet together, eyes open then closed. Be ready to catch. Positive if significant sway or fall with eyes closed.
steps.normalResult: Normal gait pattern. Romberg negative (stable with eyes closed).

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates proprioceptive loss severe enough to affect balance when visual compensation is removed. High fall risk—needs assistive device and home safety evaluation.

abnormalResults.finding: Steppage gait with bilateral foot drop
abnormalResults.significance: Patient lifts knees high to clear drooping feet. Indicates significant distal weakness. May need ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs).

clinicalPearls: The 10g monofilament is a validated screening tool for diabetic neuropathy and loss of protective sensation—inability to feel it at plantar sites indicates high ulcer risk.

Burning pain, allodynia, and nocturnal symptoms suggest small fiber involvement. Standard EMG/NCS tests only large fibers—order skin biopsy for intraepidermal nerve fiber density if small fiber neuropathy suspected.
Diabetes can cause multiple neuropathy patterns: distal symmetric polyneuropathy (most common), autonomic neuropathy, diabetic amyotrophy (proximal), and cranial neuropathies.
The ankle reflex is served by S1 and is absent in up to 30% of elderly individuals without neuropathy—always use reinforcement before declaring it absent.

title: Radiculopathy Examination
description: Focused assessment for cervical and lumbar nerve root dysfunction including root tension signs and dermatomal/myotomal testing.

steps.title: Pain Distribution Assessment
steps.instruction: Map the distribution of pain and paresthesias to identify the affected root level.
steps.technique: Ask patient to trace the path of their pain/numbness. Key patterns: C5 = lateral shoulder/arm; C6 = lateral forearm to thumb/index; C7 = posterior arm to middle finger; C8 = medial forearm to ring/small fingers; L4 = anterior thigh to medial leg; L5 = lateral leg to dorsum of foot/great toe; S1 = posterior leg to lateral foot.
steps.normalResult: No radicular pain pattern.

abnormalResults.significance: Pain following a specific dermatome strongly suggests nerve root irritation at that level. Correlate with imaging findings.
May indicate central sensitization, fibromyalgia, or non-organic etiology. Also consider myelopathy or plexopathy.

steps.title: Spurling Test (Cervical)
steps.instruction: Perform foraminal compression test to reproduce cervical radicular symptoms.
steps.technique: Have patient extend and rotate the neck toward the symptomatic side. Apply gentle axial compression to the head. Positive if this reproduces the patient's radicular arm pain (not just neck pain).
steps.normalResult: No radicular pain reproduction with cervical extension/rotation and compression.

abnormalResults.significance: 2025 meta-analysis: sensitivity 53%, specificity 92%. Low sensitivity means negative test doesn't rule out radiculopathy, but positive test strongly supports diagnosis. Mechanism: foraminal narrowing compresses the exiting nerve root.
Not a positive test—must reproduce radicular arm symptoms to be considered positive. Neck pain alone may indicate facet arthropathy or muscular strain.

steps.title: Shoulder Abduction Relief Sign
steps.instruction: Test for relief of symptoms with arm positioning.
steps.technique: Have the patient place their hand on top of their head (shoulder abduction). Ask if this relieves or worsens the arm pain/paresthesias.
steps.normalResult: No change in symptoms with arm position.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests cervical radiculopathy—this position reduces tension on the nerve root. Patients may spontaneously adopt this position.
Consider thoracic outlet syndrome or brachial plexopathy rather than cervical radiculopathy.

steps.title: Straight Leg Raise (Lasègue Test)
steps.instruction: Perform SLR to detect lower lumbar (L5-S1) nerve root tension.
steps.technique: Patient supine and relaxed. Keep knee fully extended and slowly raise the leg by the heel. Positive if this reproduces the patient's radicular leg pain (sciatica) at 30-70 degrees. Note the angle at which pain begins. Dorsiflexing the ankle at the point of pain (Braggard sign) should worsen symptoms.
steps.normalResult: Leg raises to 70-90 degrees without reproducing radicular symptoms. May feel hamstring tightness (not a positive test).

abnormalResults.significance: Cochrane meta-analysis: sensitivity 92% (pooled), specificity 28% for disc herniation. High sensitivity but low specificity—useful to rule out (negative test makes disc herniation unlikely) but many false positives. Pain must radiate below the knee.

abnormalResults.finding: Positive crossed SLR (contralateral leg raise causes ipsilateral pain)
abnormalResults.significance: Cochrane meta-analysis: sensitivity 28%, specificity 90%. Low sensitivity but high specificity—a positive crossed SLR strongly supports disc herniation. Suggests large central or paracentral disc.

abnormalResults.finding: Back pain only without leg radiation
abnormalResults.significance: Not a positive test for radiculopathy. May indicate mechanical low back pain or discogenic pain.

steps.title: Femoral Nerve Stretch Test
steps.instruction: Test for upper lumbar (L2-L4) nerve root tension.
steps.technique: Patient prone or in lateral position with affected side up. Flex the knee and extend the hip by lifting the thigh off the table. Positive if this reproduces anterior thigh pain (not just quadriceps stretch).
steps.normalResult: Hip extension with knee flexion tolerated without reproduction of radicular symptoms.

abnormalResults.significance: Suggests L2, L3, or L4 radiculopathy. Much less common than lower lumbar radiculopathy.

steps.title: Cervical Myotome Testing
steps.instruction: Test strength in muscles corresponding to each cervical root.
steps.technique: C5: Shoulder abduction (deltoid), elbow flexion (biceps). C6: Wrist extension (ECRL/B), elbow flexion (brachioradialis). C7: Elbow extension (triceps), wrist flexion. C8: Finger flexion (FDP), finger abduction (interossei). T1: Finger abduction (interossei).
steps.normalResult: Full strength (5/5) in all cervical myotomes bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Isolated weakness in a myotomal distribution localizes the radiculopathy level. Example: triceps weakness (C7), wrist drop (C7), deltoid weakness (C5).
Consider multi-level disease, brachial plexopathy, mononeuropathy multiplex, or motor neuron disease. Single root lesions typically produce limited weakness.

steps.title: Lumbar Myotome Testing
steps.instruction: Test strength in muscles corresponding to each lumbar root.
steps.technique: L2: Hip flexion (iliopsoas). L3: Knee extension (quadriceps). L4: Knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion (tibialis anterior). L5: Great toe extension (EHL), ankle dorsiflexion, hip abduction. S1: Ankle plantarflexion (gastrocnemius), ankle eversion, hip extension.
steps.normalResult: Full strength (5/5) in all lumbar myotomes bilaterally.

abnormalResults.significance: Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and great toe extension suggests L5 radiculopathy. Also consider peroneal neuropathy—check peroneal nerve at fibular head and hip abduction (L5 myotome, not peroneal).
S1 radiculopathy affects gastrocnemius. Patient may have difficulty with single-leg heel raise. Also check ankle jerk (S1).

steps.title: Root-Specific Reflexes
steps.instruction: Test reflexes that localize to specific nerve roots.
steps.technique: Biceps (C5-C6), Brachioradialis (C5-C6), Triceps (C7), Patellar (L3-L4), Achilles (S1). Compare side to side. Use reinforcement if initially absent.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric reflexes bilaterally, graded 1-2+.

abnormalResults.significance: Reflex diminution localizes the root level: depressed biceps = C5-6, depressed triceps = C7, depressed patellar = L3-4, depressed ankle = S1.

abnormalResults.finding: Hyperreflexia below the level of a cervical lesion
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests cervical myelopathy in addition to radiculopathy (myeloradiculopathy). Check for Hoffmann sign and gait abnormality.

steps.title: Dermatomal Sensory Testing
steps.instruction: Map sensory changes to confirm root level.
steps.technique: Test light touch and pinprick in dermatomal distributions. Key areas: C6 = thumb; C7 = middle finger; C8 = small finger; L4 = medial leg; L5 = dorsum of foot/great toe; S1 = lateral foot. Compare to the contralateral side.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric sensation in all dermatomes.

abnormalResults.significance: Sensory changes often less prominent than motor or reflex findings in radiculopathy. When present, helps confirm the level.
Suggests syringomyelia rather than radiculopathy. Look for suspended sensory level and dissociated sensory loss.

clinicalPearls: The most common cervical radiculopathy is C7, followed by C6. The most common lumbar radiculopathy is L5, followed by S1.
Red flags requiring urgent imaging: progressive motor weakness, bilateral symptoms, bowel/bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia (suggest cauda equina), or myelopathic signs.
Hip abduction tests L5 but NOT the peroneal nerve—use this to differentiate L5 radiculopathy from peroneal neuropathy in patients with foot drop.
Ankle reflex can be absent bilaterally in elderly patients without pathology. Unilateral loss or asymmetry is more significant.

title: Myelopathy Examination
description: Systematic assessment for spinal cord dysfunction including upper motor neuron signs, sensory level determination, and gait evaluation.

steps.title: Upper Motor Neuron Signs
steps.instruction: Test for signs of corticospinal tract dysfunction.
steps.technique: Check for spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tone with passive movement), weakness in UMN pattern (extensors weaker than flexors in arms, flexors weaker than extensors in legs), hyperreflexia, and clonus (sustained rhythmic contractions with quick dorsiflexion of ankle or wrist).
steps.normalResult: Normal tone, no clonus, reflexes 1-2+ and symmetric.

abnormalResults.significance: Upper motor neuron syndrome indicating corticospinal tract involvement. Localizes the lesion above the anterior horn cells at that level.

abnormalResults.finding: UMN signs in legs, LMN signs in arms
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests cervical myelopathy with combined cord compression and root involvement. Classic pattern in cervical spondylotic myelopathy.

steps.title: Hoffmann Sign
steps.instruction: Test for upper motor neuron dysfunction in the cervical cord.
steps.technique: Hold the patient's relaxed middle finger and quickly flick/snap the fingernail downward. Positive if this causes involuntary flexion of the thumb and index finger.
steps.normalResult: No thumb or finger flexion with fingernail flicking.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates cervical cord dysfunction when present in appropriate clinical context. Can be normal in hyperreflexic individuals—correlate with other findings.
Unilateral positivity may indicate lateralized cord compression. More significant than bilateral findings.

steps.title: Plantar Response (Babinski Sign)
steps.instruction: Test for corticospinal tract dysfunction.
steps.technique: Stroke the lateral plantar surface from heel toward the small toe, then curve medially across the metatarsal heads. Use a firm but not painful stimulus (tongue depressor, key, reflex hammer handle). Watch the great toe response.
steps.normalResult: Plantar flexion of the great toe (downgoing) or no response.

abnormalResults.finding: Upgoing great toe with fanning of other toes
abnormalResults.significance: Babinski sign positive - indicates corticospinal tract dysfunction above the L5-S1 level. One of the most reliable signs of UMN lesion.
Must distinguish true Babinski (dorsiflexion of great toe at MTP joint) from withdrawal (hip/knee flexion, ankle dorsiflexion). True Babinski requires isolated great toe extension.

steps.title: Sensory Level Determination
steps.instruction: Identify the level of spinal cord dysfunction by mapping sensory loss.
steps.technique: Test pinprick starting from the toes and moving proximally. Ask 'Does this feel sharp?' Compare each level to above. Key landmarks: T4 = nipple, T10 = umbilicus, L1 = inguinal ligament. The sensory level is typically 1-2 segments below the anatomic lesion.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric sensation throughout with no sensory level.

abnormalResults.significance: Strongly suggests spinal cord lesion. The pathologic level is typically 1-2 segments above the sensory level due to lamination of the spinothalamic tract.
Sensory loss over shoulders/arms with normal sensation above and below suggests central cord pathology such as syringomyelia.

steps.title: Posterior Column Function
steps.instruction: Test vibration and proprioception which travel in the dorsal columns.
steps.technique: Test vibration with 128 Hz tuning fork at great toe, medial malleolus, and progressively proximal. Test proprioception by moving the great toe up or down with eyes closed. Also test Romberg sign.
steps.normalResult: Intact vibration to toes, accurate proprioception, Romberg negative.

abnormalResults.finding: Loss of vibration/proprioception with preserved pain/temperature
abnormalResults.significance: Posterior column dysfunction. Consider B12 deficiency, tabes dorsalis, or posterior spinal artery syndrome if acute.
Severe proprioceptive loss. The classic 'sensory ataxia' gait is wide-based with high-stepping and looking at the feet.

steps.title: Brown-Séquard Pattern Assessment
steps.instruction: Look for the pattern of hemisection of the cord.
steps.technique: Compare motor function, proprioception/vibration, and pain/temperature between sides. Brown-Séquard: ipsilateral weakness and proprioceptive loss with contralateral pain/temperature loss below the lesion.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric motor and sensory function.

abnormalResults.significance: Cord hemisection, often from trauma, tumor, or MS. Relatively good prognosis—ambulatory function often preserved.
Incomplete hemisection more common than complete syndrome. Still localizes to a lateral cord lesion.

steps.title: Myelopathic Gait
steps.instruction: Assess gait for signs of spastic paraparesis.
steps.technique: Observe the patient walking. Look for stiff-legged gait, circumduction (swinging leg outward), scissoring (legs crossing), and difficulty with initiation. Test tandem gait (heel-to-toe walking).
steps.normalResult: Smooth gait with normal arm swing, able to tandem walk.

abnormalResults.significance: Classic myelopathic gait due to bilateral corticospinal tract involvement. Often early sign of cervical myelopathy.
Combination of corticospinal (stiffness) and posterior column (ataxia) dysfunction. Seen in B12 deficiency, MS, and compressive myelopathy.

steps.title: Bladder Function Assessment
steps.instruction: Assess for neurogenic bladder which indicates severe cord involvement.
steps.technique: Ask about urinary urgency, frequency, hesitancy, incontinence, and retention. Perform post-void residual if available. Check perineal sensation (S2-S4) and anal tone/voluntary contraction.
steps.normalResult: Normal urinary control, intact perineal sensation, normal rectal tone and voluntary squeeze.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates severe myelopathy or cauda equina syndrome. Constitutes a neurological emergency requiring urgent imaging and often surgical decompression.
Common in cervical myelopathy. Represents loss of descending inhibition on the micturition reflex (upper motor neuron bladder).

abnormalResults.finding: Absent anal wink or bulbocavernosus reflex
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests sacral cord or conus involvement. In trauma, absence beyond 24 hours indicates complete injury with poor prognosis.

steps.title: Lhermitte Sign
steps.instruction: Test for electric shock sensation with neck flexion indicating cervical cord pathology.
steps.technique: Ask patient if they experience an electric shock or tingling sensation down the spine or into the limbs when bending the neck forward. If history is unclear, have patient flex chin to chest while you observe for symptoms.
steps.normalResult: No electric shock sensation with neck flexion.

abnormalResults.finding: Positive Lhermitte sign (electric shock down spine/limbs)
abnormalResults.significance: Sensitivity ~16%, specificity 97% for myelopathy. Low sensitivity means absence doesn't rule out cord disease, but presence strongly suggests cervical cord pathology. Causes: MS (9-41% of patients), cervical spondylotic myelopathy, B12 deficiency, radiation myelopathy.

clinicalPearls: Cervical myelopathy is a clinical diagnosis—MRI may show cord compression but clinical correlation is essential. Asymptomatic cord compression is common in the elderly.
Lhermitte sign (electric shock down the spine with neck flexion) suggests posterior column involvement in the cervical cord. Classic in MS but also seen in B12 deficiency and cervical spondylosis.
Acute myelopathy with back pain and sensory level is a neurological emergency—obtain urgent MRI to evaluate for cord compression, transverse myelitis, or spinal cord infarction.
Hand clumsiness and difficulty with fine motor tasks (buttoning, writing) is often an early sign of cervical myelopathy before significant weakness develops.

title: Movement Disorder Examination
description: Systematic assessment of tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and abnormal movements to characterize movement disorders.

steps.title: Observation at Rest
steps.instruction: Observe the patient at rest for involuntary movements before any active testing.
steps.technique: Have the patient sit quietly with hands resting in their lap. Observe for 30-60 seconds for tremor, chorea, dystonic posturing, myoclonus, or tics. Note the distribution, frequency, and amplitude of any movements.
steps.normalResult: No involuntary movements at rest. Hands still and relaxed.

abnormalResults.significance: Pill-rolling rest tremor at 4-6 Hz is highly characteristic of Parkinson disease. Asymmetric onset is typical. Tremor decreases with movement.
Random, flowing, dance-like involuntary movements suggest Huntington disease, Sydenham chorea, or medication-induced (tardive) chorea.
Sustained abnormal postures (e.g., torticollis, writer's cramp) indicate dystonia. Note if task-specific or present at rest.

steps.title: Tremor Characterization
steps.instruction: Determine if tremor is present at rest, with posture, or with action.
steps.technique: Rest: hands in lap. Postural: arms outstretched with fingers spread. Kinetic: finger-nose testing. Intention: observe for worsening as finger approaches target. Note frequency (count cycles per second) and amplitude.
steps.normalResult: No tremor, or minimal physiologic tremor with posture (8-12 Hz, low amplitude).

abnormalResults.significance: Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder. Usually symmetric, often improves with alcohol, may have family history.
Worsening tremor as the finger approaches target indicates cerebellar dysfunction. Look for other cerebellar signs (dysarthria, nystagmus, gait ataxia).
Large amplitude, low frequency proximal tremor with arms outstretched suggests Wilson disease. Check for Kayser-Fleischer rings and liver disease.

steps.title: Bradykinesia Assessment
steps.instruction: Test for slowness and decrement in repetitive movements.
steps.technique: Finger tapping: Have patient tap index finger and thumb together as fast and big as possible, 10-15 times. Observe for amplitude, speed, and decrement. Also test hand opening/closing and foot tapping. Test each side separately.
steps.normalResult: Rapid, full-amplitude repetitive movements without decrement or hesitation.

abnormalResults.finding: Progressive decrement in amplitude and speed
abnormalResults.significance: Bradykinesia with decrement is the defining feature of Parkinson disease. Movement starts reasonably then progressively becomes smaller and slower.
Slowness without the characteristic decrement may indicate drug-induced parkinsonism, PSP, or other atypical parkinsonism.

steps.title: Rigidity Assessment
steps.instruction: Test for increased resistance to passive movement.
steps.technique: With patient relaxed, passively move the wrist and elbow through full range of flexion/extension. Feel for resistance that is: uniform throughout range (lead-pipe) or ratchety (cogwheel—lead-pipe plus tremor). Use activation maneuver: have patient clench opposite fist while you test to bring out subtle rigidity.
steps.normalResult: No resistance to passive movement. Joints move freely.

abnormalResults.significance: Lead-pipe rigidity with superimposed tremor creates a ratchety feel. Characteristic of Parkinson disease and drug-induced parkinsonism.

abnormalResults.finding: Rigidity brought out only with activation
abnormalResults.significance: Subtle early parkinsonism. The contralateral activation maneuver increases sensitivity for detecting mild rigidity.
This is spasticity, not rigidity. Suggests upper motor neuron lesion rather than extrapyramidal disorder.

steps.title: Postural Stability (Pull Test)
steps.instruction: Assess postural reflexes to detect balance impairment.
steps.technique: Stand behind the patient and explain you will pull them backward. Ask them to catch themselves. Give a firm, quick pull on the shoulders. Be ready to catch them. Normal: catches self in 1-2 steps. Abnormal: retropulsion (multiple steps back) or would fall without catching.
steps.normalResult: Patient recovers balance with 1-2 steps.

abnormalResults.significance: Postural instability indicates later-stage Parkinson disease (H&Y stage 3+) and significantly increases fall risk. Also prominent in PSP.

abnormalResults.finding: Falls like a log without attempting to catch self
abnormalResults.significance: Absent postural reflexes suggest progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP). These patients often have frequent backward falls with injuries.

steps.title: Parkinsonian Gait Assessment
steps.instruction: Observe gait for features of parkinsonism.
steps.technique: Watch patient walk at least 20 feet, turn, and return. Note: start hesitation, step length, arm swing, trunk posture, turning (en bloc vs normal), freezing. Ask patient to walk quickly and observe if gait improves or worsens.
steps.normalResult: Normal stride length, symmetric arm swing, upright posture, smooth turning.

abnormalResults.finding: Shuffling gait with reduced arm swing
abnormalResults.significance: Classic parkinsonian gait: short, shuffling steps, stooped posture, reduced arm swing (often asymmetric early in disease).
Progressively faster, shorter steps as if chasing center of gravity forward. Patient may have difficulty stopping. Falls risk.
Sudden inability to initiate or continue walking, especially at doorways or when turning. Later-stage feature, often medication-resistant.

steps.title: Facial Expression (Hypomimia)
steps.instruction: Assess facial expression and blinking.
steps.technique: Observe the patient's face during conversation. Note the range of facial expression, presence of spontaneous smiling, and blink rate. Ask patient to smile and note if spontaneous facial expression returns.
steps.normalResult: Animated facial expressions, normal blink rate (15-20/min).

abnormalResults.significance: Hypomimia ('masked face') is a classic sign of Parkinson disease. Reduced blink rate is common. Can be mistaken for depression.
Characteristic of progressive supranuclear palsy. Frontalis muscle overactivity combined with reduced blinking creates a staring appearance.

steps.title: Dystonia Assessment
steps.instruction: Evaluate for sustained abnormal postures and task-specific movements.
steps.technique: Observe for abnormal posturing at rest. Test for task-specific dystonia: have patient write (writer's cramp), play instrument if musician, or perform their symptomatic task. Note if sensory tricks (geste antagoniste) relieve symptoms—e.g., touching chin relieves cervical dystonia.
steps.normalResult: Normal posture, no involuntary muscle contractions with tasks.

abnormalResults.significance: Head turning or tilting due to involuntary neck muscle contraction. Most common adult-onset focal dystonia. Treat with botulinum toxin.
Abnormal posturing only during specific tasks (writing, playing instrument). Occupational significance. May respond to retraining and botulinum toxin.
Light touch to affected area relieves dystonia—highly specific for dystonia. Not present in other movement disorders.

clinicalPearls: The cardinal features of parkinsonism are TRAP: Tremor (rest), Rigidity, Akinesia/bradykinesia, Postural instability. At least 2 are required for diagnosis, with bradykinesia being essential.
Asymmetric onset and excellent levodopa response favor idiopathic Parkinson disease. Symmetric onset, early falls, and poor levodopa response suggest atypical parkinsonism.
Drug-induced parkinsonism (from dopamine blockers) is the second most common cause of parkinsonism. It is usually symmetric and reversible.

Essential tremor is distinguished from Parkinson disease by: postural/kinetic > rest tremor, usually symmetric, often improves with alcohol, no bradykinesia/rigidity, and positive family history in 50%.

title: Myasthenia Gravis Examination
description: Focused assessment for fatigable weakness characteristic of neuromuscular junction disorders.

steps.title: Ptosis Assessment
steps.instruction: Evaluate for eyelid drooping and fatigability.
steps.technique: Observe for asymmetric ptosis at rest. Measure palpebral fissure width (margin-reflex distance). Perform sustained upgaze test: have patient look up at your finger for 60-120 seconds. Observe for increasing ptosis. Positive if ptosis worsens or develops with sustained upgaze.
steps.normalResult: Symmetric eyelids, no ptosis. Can maintain upgaze for 2 minutes without ptosis developing.

abnormalResults.significance: Ptosis that worsens with sustained upgaze is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis. Unilateral or asymmetric ptosis is common.
Brief upward overshoot of the lid when looking from down to straight ahead. Specific for myasthenia gravis.
When ptotic lid is manually elevated, the other lid droops more. Indicates bilateral involvement with compensation.

steps.title: Ice Pack Test
steps.instruction: Perform bedside test to support MG diagnosis.
steps.technique: If ptosis is present, apply an ice pack or cold compress to the closed eyelids for 2 minutes. Remeasure ptosis immediately after removal. Improvement of ≥2mm is positive.
steps.normalResult: No change in ptosis with ice application.

abnormalResults.significance: Systematic review (2023): sensitivity 76-92%, specificity 79-98% for MG with ptosis. Cold improves neuromuscular transmission by slowing acetylcholinesterase activity. Most useful when ptosis is present; less validated for diplopia alone.

steps.title: Diplopia and Eye Movement Assessment
steps.instruction: Evaluate for fatigable ophthalmoparesis.
steps.technique: Test extraocular movements in all directions of gaze. Have patient perform sustained lateral gaze for 30-60 seconds. Look for nystagmus that develops with sustained gaze (gaze-evoked nystagmus) or worsening diplopia. Note any pattern of muscle weakness.
steps.normalResult: Full extraocular movements in all directions. No diplopia with sustained gaze.

abnormalResults.significance: Classic for myasthenia gravis. Any pattern of eye muscle weakness can occur, often mimicking cranial nerve palsies.
Adduction weakness resembling INO but due to medial rectus fatigue in MG. Pupil sparing distinguishes from true INO.

steps.title: Facial and Bulbar Weakness
steps.instruction: Assess facial strength and fatigability.
steps.technique: Have patient squeeze eyes shut tightly against your attempt to open them. Observe for 'peek sign' (sclera becoming visible). Test orbicularis oris: have patient puff out cheeks against your compression. Note any facial weakness pattern.
steps.normalResult: Strong eye closure, cannot pry open lids. Strong cheek puff.

abnormalResults.significance: Sclera becomes visible despite patient's attempt to keep eyes closed. Indicates orbicularis oculi weakness. Relatively specific for MG.
Attempted smile produces a snarling appearance due to lateral lip weakness with relative sparing of medial smile. Characteristic of MG.

steps.title: Speech and Swallowing Assessment
steps.instruction: Evaluate for bulbar symptoms and fatigability.
steps.technique: Have patient count to 50 or read aloud for 60 seconds. Listen for hypernasality, dysarthria that worsens (fatigable), or voice that fades. Ask about dysphagia, choking, nasal regurgitation.
steps.normalResult: Clear speech that maintains quality throughout counting. No swallowing complaints.

abnormalResults.significance: Speech becomes increasingly nasal or slurred with prolonged talking. Indicates bulbar involvement—consider aspiration risk.
Palatal weakness allows nasal escape of air (hypernasality) and liquids (regurgitation). Significant bulbar involvement with aspiration risk.

steps.title: Neck Flexion Strength
steps.instruction: Test neck flexor strength and fatigability.
steps.technique: Have patient lie supine and lift head off the pillow against gravity. Time how long they can maintain this position (normally >60 seconds). Then test against resistance: place hand on forehead and have patient flex neck against it.
steps.normalResult: Holds head up >60 seconds without difficulty. Strong neck flexion against resistance.

abnormalResults.significance: Cannot hold head up for 60 seconds. Neck flexors are commonly affected in MG. Correlates with respiratory muscle weakness.
Severe neck extensor weakness. While can be seen in MG, also consider other conditions (ALS, inflammatory myopathy).

steps.title: Limb Weakness and Fatigability
steps.instruction: Test for proximal weakness and fatigability in limbs.
steps.technique: Test shoulder abduction and hip flexion. Have patient hold arms abducted to 90° for 60-120 seconds. Observe for progressive arm drift or inability to maintain position. Repeat strength testing after fatigue maneuver.
steps.normalResult: Maintains arm abduction for >2 minutes. No change in strength with repeated testing.

abnormalResults.significance: Arm abduction strength decreases with sustained effort. Pattern is proximal > distal, similar to myopathy but distinguished by fatigability.

abnormalResults.finding: Weakness that improves with repeated testing
abnormalResults.significance: Consider Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS). In LEMS, strength may briefly improve with repeated effort (facilitation).

steps.title: Respiratory Function
steps.instruction: Assess for respiratory muscle involvement.
steps.technique: Observe respiratory pattern for use of accessory muscles, abdominal paradox. Have patient count to 20 in one breath (normally possible). If available, measure forced vital capacity (FVC) and negative inspiratory force (NIF).
steps.normalResult: Counts to 20 in one breath easily. No accessory muscle use. FVC >80% predicted.

abnormalResults.finding: Cannot count to 10-15 in one breath
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests reduced vital capacity. Monitor closely—FVC <1L or NIF weaker than -20 cmH2O may require intubation.
Abdomen moves inward during inspiration (opposite of normal). Indicates diaphragm weakness—impending respiratory failure. ICU admission warranted.

clinicalPearls: MG has a bimodal age distribution: young women (20-30s) and older men (60-70s). Thymoma is associated with older-onset MG.
The ice pack test is useful in ED or clinic when edrophonium testing is not available. It has comparable sensitivity and specificity.

FVC and NIF should be monitored serially in admitted patients—a declining trend is more important than absolute values. The '20-30-40 rule': FVC <20 mL/kg, NIF > -30 cmH2O, or >30% decline in either predicts need for intubation.
Crisis triggers include infection, surgery, medications (aminoglycosides, beta-blockers, magnesium), and medication non-compliance. Always ask about triggers.
Patients with pure ocular MG for >2 years have <15% chance of generalizing. Generalized MG typically develops within 2 years of ocular onset.

title: ICU Neurological Check
description: Rapid, standardized bedside assessment for monitoring neurological status in critically ill patients.

steps.title: Level of Consciousness
steps.instruction: Assess alertness and responsiveness using a standardized scale.
steps.technique: Call the patient's name. If no response, apply a trapezius squeeze or nailbed pressure. Document response using GCS (Eye, Verbal, Motor) or FOUR score. Note any change from previous assessment.
steps.normalResult: Alert, oriented, follows commands (GCS 15, FOUR 16).

abnormalResults.significance: Significant neurological decline requiring immediate evaluation. Consider repeat imaging, check for metabolic/infectious causes.
GCS eye score of 1 indicates severe impairment. Evaluate for brainstem function and consider prognostic implications.

steps.title: Pupil Examination
steps.instruction: Assess pupil size, symmetry, and reactivity.
steps.technique: Dim room lights. Note pupil size in mm for each eye. Shine bright light directly into each eye and observe for constriction (direct response) and constriction in the opposite eye (consensual response). Document briskness: brisk, sluggish, or fixed.
steps.normalResult: Pupils equal, round, reactive to light (PERRL), 2-4mm.

abnormalResults.significance: Possible uncal herniation with CN III compression—neurosurgical emergency. Confirm with other signs of herniation and obtain immediate imaging.
May indicate severe bilateral herniation, anticholinergic toxicity, or hypothermia. In the setting of cardiac arrest, poor prognostic sign.
Consider pontine lesion (hemorrhage) or opioid effect. Pontine hemorrhage also causes hyperthermia and abnormal respirations.

steps.title: Brainstem Reflexes
steps.instruction: Test corneal reflex and cough/gag in intubated patients.
steps.technique: Corneal: Touch cornea (not sclera) with saline-moistened cotton and observe for blink bilaterally. Cough: Suction through ETT and observe for cough response. Gag: Touch posterior pharynx with tongue depressor if accessible.
steps.normalResult: Brisk bilateral corneal reflexes. Strong cough with suctioning.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates CN V (afferent) or CN VII (efferent) dysfunction, or brainstem depression. Document which side(s) affected.
Suggests severe brainstem dysfunction. Important for brain death evaluation but must be interpreted in context.

steps.title: Motor Response
steps.instruction: Assess motor function in all four extremities.
steps.technique: If patient follows commands: 'Squeeze my fingers', 'Lift your legs', 'Give thumbs up'. If not following commands, apply nailbed pressure to each extremity and observe response: localizes, withdraws, flexion posturing, extension posturing, or none.
steps.normalResult: Follows commands symmetrically in all extremities.

abnormalResults.significance: Possible new stroke, worsening edema, or hemorrhage expansion. Compare to baseline and consider repeat imaging.
Arms flexed, legs extended indicates lesion above the red nucleus. Poor prognosis but better than decerebrate.
Arms and legs extended indicates lesion at or below the red nucleus (midbrain/pons). Very poor prognosis.

steps.title: Respiratory Pattern
steps.instruction: Observe breathing pattern in non-intubated patients or respiratory drive in intubated patients.
steps.technique: Observe respiratory rate, depth, and pattern. Classic abnormal patterns: Cheyne-Stokes (crescendo-decrescendo), central hyperventilation, apneustic (prolonged inspiration), ataxic (irregular). In intubated patients, note if breathing over the ventilator rate.
steps.normalResult: Regular respiratory pattern, 12-20 breaths/min. Breathing above ventilator rate if intubated.

abnormalResults.significance: Crescendo-decrescendo pattern indicates bilateral hemispheric or diencephalic dysfunction. May also be seen with heart failure.
Completely irregular pattern indicates medullary dysfunction—often preterminal. Prepare for possible respiratory arrest.
Absent ventilatory drive above set rate may indicate brainstem depression. Important data point for brain death evaluation.

clinicalPearls: Standardize your neuro check to perform elements in the same order every time. This helps detect subtle changes on serial exams.
The most important aspect of ICU neuro checks is detecting CHANGE from baseline. Document detailed findings to enable comparison.
Sedation profoundly affects the neurological exam. Document sedation medications, recent doses, and time since last dose with each neuro check.
When in doubt about a change, repeat the exam in 30 minutes. Consult neurology if persistent decline or concern for acute event.

title: Pathological Reflexes Examination
description: Assessment of abnormal reflexes indicating upper motor neuron dysfunction or frontal lobe pathology.

steps.title: Babinski Sign (Plantar Response)
steps.instruction: Elicit the plantar reflex to assess corticospinal tract integrity.
steps.technique: With a blunt object (key, tongue depressor), stroke the lateral sole from heel toward the toes, then curve medially across the metatarsal heads. Use firm pressure but avoid pain. Watch the great toe and other toes.
steps.normalResult: Plantar flexion (downward movement) of the great toe, or no response.

abnormalResults.finding: Upgoing (extensor) great toe with fanning of other toes
abnormalResults.significance: Babinski sign positive. Sensitivity ~90%, specificity ~100% for corticospinal tract lesions (Van Gijn 1978). Few false positives; occasionally absent despite pyramidal disease due to coexisting LMN lesion or spinal shock.
Hip flexion, knee flexion, and ankle dorsiflexion is a withdrawal, not a true Babinski. Indicates intact reflex arc but must be distinguished from upgoing toe.

steps.title: Babinski Sign Variants
steps.instruction: Use alternative methods when standard plantar response is difficult to interpret.
steps.technique: Chaddock: Stroke lateral foot from ankle toward small toe. Oppenheim: Firm downward stroke along tibial shin. Gordon: Squeeze the calf. Schaefer: Squeeze the Achilles tendon. All should produce upgoing toe if Babinski positive.
steps.normalResult: Downgoing or no toe response with all maneuvers.

abnormalResults.significance: Same significance as positive Babinski sign. Variants are useful when the sole is calloused, hypersensitive, or the standard response is equivocal.

steps.title: Hoffmann Sign
steps.instruction: Test for cervical cord dysfunction.
steps.technique: Hold the patient's middle finger relaxed between your thumb and index finger. Flick/snap the distal phalanx (fingernail) downward. Watch for involuntary flexion of the thumb and index finger.
steps.normalResult: No finger flexion response.

abnormalResults.finding: Brisk thumb and index finger flexion
abnormalResults.significance: Systematic review (2018): sensitivity 8-59%, specificity 49-85% for cervical myelopathy. High variability limits diagnostic utility in isolation. Positive LR only 2.2—insufficient alone to confirm or exclude myelopathy. Best interpreted with other UMN signs.
Asymmetry is more significant than bilateral presence. Suggests lateralized cervical cord pathology.

steps.title: Clonus
steps.instruction: Test for sustained rhythmic contractions indicating hyperreflexia.
steps.technique: Ankle clonus: With knee slightly flexed, rapidly dorsiflex the foot and maintain pressure. Sustained rhythmic beats indicate clonus. Patellar clonus: Push patella sharply downward while knee extended. Count the number of beats.
steps.normalResult: No clonus, or 1-2 unsustained beats.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates UMN dysfunction with hyperreflexia. Sustained clonus (>10 beats or inexhaustible) indicates significant corticospinal tract pathology.

steps.title: Frontal Release Signs (Primitive Reflexes)
steps.instruction: Test for reflexes that are normal in infants but pathological in adults.
steps.technique: Grasp: Stroke the patient's palm—grasp response is involuntary gripping. Palmomental: Stroke thenar eminence—watch for ipsilateral chin muscle contraction. Snout: Tap upper lip—watch for lip pursing. Glabellar: Repeatedly tap glabella—normally habituation occurs after 3-5 taps.
steps.normalResult: No grasp, palmomental, or snout response. Glabellar tap habituates.

abnormalResults.significance: Involuntary gripping indicates contralateral frontal lobe dysfunction (supplementary motor area). Highly localizing when unilateral.
Least specific frontal release sign—may be present in normal elderly. More significant when brisk and easily elicited.

abnormalResults.finding: Failure to habituate to glabellar tap (Myerson sign)
abnormalResults.significance: Continued blinking despite repeated taps suggests frontal dysfunction. Classic in Parkinson disease and other frontal pathology.
Presence of multiple primitive reflexes suggests significant bifrontal dysfunction. Common in advanced dementia, normal pressure hydrocephalus, and diffuse frontal damage.

steps.title: Jaw Jerk Reflex
steps.instruction: Assess for UMN dysfunction above the pons.
steps.technique: With the patient's mouth slightly open and relaxed, place your finger on the chin. Tap your finger with a reflex hammer. Watch for jaw closure. A brisk response or clonus is abnormal.
steps.normalResult: Absent or minimal jaw closure.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates bilateral UMN dysfunction above the mid-pons. Helpful in differentiating UMN (brisk) from LMN (absent) causes of dysarthria/dysphagia.
Strongly suggests bilateral corticobulbar dysfunction as seen in pseudobulbar palsy, ALS, or bilateral hemispheric disease.

clinicalPearls: The Babinski sign is the most reliable pathological reflex. It is always abnormal in adults (except briefly after seizures or during sleep).
Frontal release signs exist on a spectrum—a single palmomental reflex may be normal in elderly. Multiple strong primitive reflexes indicate significant pathology.
Hoffman sign can be normal in hyperreflexic individuals. Asymmetry is more significant than bilateral presence. Always correlate with other UMN signs.
A brisk jaw jerk helps distinguish pseudobulbar (UMN) from bulbar (LMN) palsy in patients with dysarthria and dysphagia.

title: Peripheral Nerve Entrapment Examination
description: Bedside tests for common nerve entrapment syndromes including carpal tunnel, cubital tunnel, and other compression neuropathies.

steps.title: Phalen Test (Wrist Flexion)
steps.instruction: Test for median nerve compression at the carpal tunnel.
steps.technique: Have patient hold both wrists in maximal flexion (backs of hands pressed together) for 60 seconds. Positive if paresthesias occur in the median nerve distribution (thumb, index, middle, radial half of ring finger).
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias with 60 seconds of sustained wrist flexion.

abnormalResults.significance: Sensitivity 67-85%, specificity 89-93% for carpal tunnel syndrome. More specific than sensitive—positive test supports diagnosis. Time to symptom onset correlates with severity (shorter = more severe).

steps.title: Reverse Phalen Test (Prayer Sign)
steps.instruction: Alternative carpal tunnel test using wrist extension.
steps.technique: Have patient hold wrists in maximal dorsiflexion (palms pressed together, prayer position) for 60 seconds. Positive if median nerve paresthesias occur.
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias with sustained wrist extension.

abnormalResults.significance: May be positive when standard Phalen is negative. Both positions increase carpal tunnel pressure, but through different mechanisms.

steps.title: Tinel Sign at Wrist
steps.instruction: Percuss over the median nerve at the carpal tunnel.
steps.technique: Tap firmly over the volar wrist at the carpal tunnel (between the tendons of palmaris longus and flexor carpi radialis). Positive if electric shock or tingling radiates into the thumb, index, or middle fingers.
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias with percussion over carpal tunnel.

abnormalResults.finding: Tingling radiating into median nerve distribution
abnormalResults.significance: Meta-analysis: median sensitivity 51%, specificity 90%. Low sensitivity but high specificity—positive test supports CTS diagnosis but negative test doesn't exclude it. Less useful than Phalen.

steps.title: Durkan Test (Carpal Compression)
steps.instruction: Apply direct pressure over the carpal tunnel.
steps.technique: Apply firm pressure with both thumbs directly over the carpal tunnel for 30 seconds. Positive if this reproduces median nerve paresthesias.
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias with carpal tunnel compression.

abnormalResults.significance: May have higher sensitivity than Tinel (up to 87%) with similar specificity. Directly compresses the median nerve in the carpal tunnel.

steps.title: Tinel Sign at Elbow (Cubital Tunnel)
steps.instruction: Test for ulnar nerve compression at the elbow.
steps.technique: Tap over the ulnar nerve in the cubital tunnel (groove between medial epicondyle and olecranon). Positive if electric shock or tingling radiates into the ring and small fingers.
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias or mild local sensation only.

abnormalResults.finding: Tingling radiating to ring and small fingers
abnormalResults.significance: Suggests ulnar neuropathy at the elbow (cubital tunnel syndrome). Sensitivity and specificity variable. Should be combined with elbow flexion test and motor/sensory exam.

steps.title: Elbow Flexion Test
steps.instruction: Provocative test for cubital tunnel syndrome.
steps.technique: Have patient maximally flex the elbow with wrist extended for 60 seconds, or combine with direct pressure over the cubital tunnel. Positive if ulnar nerve symptoms (paresthesias in ring/small fingers) occur.
steps.normalResult: No paresthesias with sustained elbow flexion.

abnormalResults.significance: Elbow flexion increases pressure in the cubital tunnel and stretches the ulnar nerve. Combined elbow flexion + direct pressure has sensitivity ~91%.

steps.title: Froment Sign
steps.instruction: Test for ulnar nerve motor weakness (adductor pollicis).
steps.technique: Ask patient to pinch a piece of paper between thumb and index finger (key grip) while you try to pull it away. Watch the thumb IP joint. Positive if the thumb IP joint flexes (compensatory FPL activation).
steps.normalResult: Thumb remains straight at IP joint during pinch grip.

abnormalResults.finding: Thumb IP flexion during key pinch (Froment positive)
abnormalResults.significance: Indicates adductor pollicis weakness from ulnar neuropathy. The flexor pollicis longus (median nerve) compensates for weak adductor pollicis (ulnar nerve).

steps.title: Wartenberg Sign
steps.instruction: Test for ulnar nerve weakness affecting finger adduction.
steps.technique: Ask patient to hold fingers tightly together with hand flat. Observe the small finger. Positive if the small finger drifts into abduction and cannot be brought back to other fingers.
steps.normalResult: Small finger adducts normally with other fingers.

abnormalResults.significance: Indicates weakness of the third palmar interosseous (ulnar nerve). The unopposed extensor digiti minimi causes small finger abduction.

clinicalPearls: For carpal tunnel syndrome: Phalen test is more sensitive (67-85%) than Tinel (51%). Durkan (carpal compression) may be most sensitive (up to 87%). Combine multiple tests for better accuracy.

In cubital tunnel syndrome, the elbow flexion test combined with direct pressure over the nerve has the highest sensitivity. Always assess motor function (Froment, Wartenberg) alongside sensory tests.
No single provocative test is sufficient for diagnosis—electrodiagnostic studies remain the gold standard when clinical diagnosis is uncertain.
